Reddish brown brew with a small amount of off-white head.  Nose of pitted fruit, berries, and oak.  Taste is tart with some earth and more fruit.

Shared at WTWBA 2012, Brooklyn.  The aroma is sour, tart cherries.  The appearance is dark brown/red, off-white head.  The flavor is sour, tart cherries.  The finish is sour, vinegar-like, no fruit.  Pretty good.

22 oz. bottle, split courtesy of uhlan (thanks Gerry!), pours a beautiful ruby red with a small beige head. Aroma is uber-complex, with sour cherries, sweet candied sugar, some candy floss and light acidity. The flavour reveals more of the acidity, but also dominated by sour cherries, medium sweetness, some amaretto liqueur, and quite a lot of booze, despite this having been a 2-year old bottle. Couldnt drink a lot of this, but in smaller samples, this is exquisite. Very complex and refined.
Poured a nice reddish brown. Had a sour cherry smell and taste. Hints of pear and oak. Purchased in 2008 it aged very well. I loved this one.

pours a copper red with a minimal head. aroma is beast, typical flanders with a strong sour cherry note. taste isnt as good, medicinal notes overpower flanders taste and sour cherries fade to the finish, i am a bit disappointed, this is not as good as i expected. off tastes effect the mouthfeel, almost puts the brakes on my tastebuds, ill take a red poppy any day over this
Bottle from marcus. Color is brown with an off white head. Aroma is woody an sour. Taste has a nice oak barrel taste that finishes sour.

Pour a nice mahogany red with a 1/4 of carb. Smells is really interesting on this one... I almost get a vomit smell, i typically do though with oude bruins. I do smell the barrel though as well. I can taste the dark fruits in this but the mild acidicy takes over. I like it for what it is but once is enough for me.

Starts with a nice blend of sweet and sour cherries. A bit of funk and tartness follows. Notes of oak follow at the end. Really, this beer has a lot of tartness, but not a lot of true sourness. My only real problem is the alcohol content. Its too boozy. Theres this tug-o-war going on between the sour and alcohol burn that takes away from the enjoyment of the beer. 

Still, Its quite good.

2010 Bottle served in a tulip. Pours deep amber with a short head. Minimal retention and lace. Bright red cherry aroma with oak in the head, honeysuckle-candy notes in the elixir, and a persistent sour tone. Very appealing. Medium sweet flavor of cherry, oak, and lemon. Light-medium body, solid carbonation, sticky-thin texture, and a moderately sour, fruity finish. The cherry buries the brett for me, leaving minimal yeast fingerprints. This could be my favorite Deschutes beer.

2010 bottle bought at GBBF 2011, shared with Trapissed.
Dark brown beer with stewed fruits and brett on the nose. In flavour its not as lactic as expected, with some acetic notes. Fairly carbonated and acidic texture...lemon juice. Its towards rodenbach on the sours scale. No notice of the cherries.
Paired with langres washed rind cheese

About 2 years old now, 2010 bottle. The sour pours almost murky amber brown with a cherry hue and a big beige bubbly head. The aroma still has sweet cherry notes and tarty Brett notes as well. The flavor brings a huge Bretty Flanders Red, no resiny sweetness but super tart Brett flavors with the cherries bringing nice notes as well on a well medium thick body. There is still very much a warm alcohol presence that settles withe the body right on the palate - wow..
Draft at Beer Revolution. Flat cloudy amber color. Aroma of malty summer fruits. Taste is boozy lemon, grapefruit. Very nice.

Tap at Beer Revolution. Pours a chill hazed clearer strawberry with no head. Nose is quite nice: mild sour strawberry and raspberry with hanssens fruit lambic style funk. Taste is tangy, effervescent, mixed sweet and sour berry medley. Almost blackberry character. Palate is tangy, sharp, a bit papery. Not a big acetic character thankfully.

pours a hazy gold. Aroma is a bit cherry and a touch sour apple. Flavor is very sour and tart. Has a bit of a pepper or spicey finish.

2010 vintage from cbkschbert. Pours clear light brown color with tan head. Aromas of sour cherries, oak and brett. Fruity and sour flavor, bretty and earthy with some oak. Meduim body with average carbonation. Very nice. Thanks Craig.

22 oz bottle.  Color is deep amber copper.  Smells of vibrant sour cherries and apple breads and pies, with a hint of cheese.  Rich supple, dry fruity medium body and a long, toasted grain bread, peppery spice and earthy/barky hop accented finish.  Tremendous complexity and richness to this beer.

Bomber from 2010. Slightly hazy amber with a creamy biege head that fades quickly. A nice sour aroma that is moderated with some grains, malt and wood. Also get some fruit/grapes, some alcohol, bit of candied sugar. Medium body, tart, becomes dry and quite fruity, little bit sweet at the end.

This poured a dark red color with a pinkish biege head. Aroma was lots of tart cherries, some wine, and lots of yeast and brett.  Flavor was medium tartness, not mouth puckering but definitely up front,s oem dark fruit and wood characters too. Decent.

Fall 2011 Ratebeer gathering. +++ Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured a hazy bright red-orange color with a small tan head that faded quickly and left no lacing. The aroma was tart and sour caramel and vinegar. The flavor was tart with notes of tea, cherry, berry and must. Medium body. Complex but odd.
2010.  Clear orange-red, off white cover.  Aroma is nicely tart,, Taste is a bit of acidic tart, cherry,
UPDATED: MAR 5, 2012 Bomber, red clear beer. Tart and cherry in the aroma. Slight oak. Taste is a great balance. Tart, cherry, some oak. Base beer is still in tact, which is pretty rare. Great job!

2008 bottle. Nice lactic, acetic nose, cherry, light chocolate. Oh-so-light funk. Deep red, cloudy, with lace. Dry, dusty flavor, cherry, clean, though dirty. Low sweetness. Very dry and slightly tart. An interesting dry take on the style. Like it.

22oz Bottle. Thanks for sharing Sean! Wonderful soft, mineral and red fruit aroma. Yum. Yeasty up front, with a touch of plastic, but then a graceful slide towards malty delight and a tangy snap. Some ruby red grapefruit, raspberry sauce, and cherry. A good bit delicate and soft, in the Belgian way. Very enjoyable and nice soft American sour.

This poured an amber color with a white head. The aroma contains some cherries, nutmeg, cinammon, and vinegar. The flavor is slightly sour with some cherries, pumpkin?, spices. Some alcohol showing in the finish. Overall a good and interesting beer.

Bottle (from GBBF 2011) at Leightons Aug 11 tasting. It pours red-orange, with a thin off-white head. The nose is sour cherry, cranberry, raspberry, blueberry, malt vinegar and lactic acid. The taste is sweeter than expected: blackcurrant, glazier cherry, blueberry, light malt vinegar, almond, Playdough and some alcohol warmth. Medium body,  fine carbonation and light tartness. Decent, but I wish it had a bigger sour kick.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Snifter.

Appearance: Bright brownish-amber with almost a pinkish hue. Not much head or lacing after the initial pour.

Aroma: Tart cherries, brown sugar, pepper and a light farmhouse funk. Overall impression of vinegary olives - per my wife but I agree.

Taste: Strong cherry, with a biting tartness. More biting than truly sour. There is both an underlying caramel sweetness and an underlying peppery dryness, which complement one another nicely. Slight impressions of oak.

Palate: Moderate carbonation, slightly smooth medium body, tart and dry finish.

Overall: This is one of those beers I appreciate more than love. No matter how well crafted this is, I have a hard time getting past the strong cherry flavor. I likely would have preferred this without the addition of cherries. Still, it is a nice sipping beer that I am very happy to have finally tried.

Sampled a 2008 and a 2010, numerical rating is for the 2008, the higher rated of the two - although they were both very good. Both are reddish copper, with a thin ring of foam. 2008 smells like balsamic vinegar, some chocolate, and some cinnamon. Flavors are spicy cinnamon, some vegetal notes, very citrusy sour notes. The 2010 is similar, maybe not as well melded yet. Tasty stuff.

Bottle at a tasting, thanks to Paul. Pours clear amber with a fine, white head. Has a pretty dynamic aroma, featuring tart berries, caramel, toast, grapes, wood. Very sweet flavor with some detectable alcohol, tart berries, slight funk. Full bodied with fine to average carbonation. Warm finish, medium tartness, booze, caramel, berries, sugar, wood. Very good stuff.

Sample at a tasting at Suttrees. 2008 bottle: Pours clear reddish orange with offwhite head. Very musty, moldy, dank nose with hint of malty sweetness. The flavor is slight raisin with some lactic sourness, vanilla, and oak. Maybe some cinnamon? 2010: similar to 2008, with a bit more of a brown sugar taste and some autumnal spices that comes across like a soured pumpkin ale.

2008. Amber pour, minimal head. Light vinegar meets w touch of backyard funk in the aroma. Sour but plenty of barn musty funk. Socks. Wood is also there as is cinnamon (esp. In the 2010) Joe says sour pumpkin and he is on the money (2010).  Wet medium body.

Bottle from GBBF 2011 drunk at home.  Wow that is a sour aroma.  Some obvious alcohol on the finish.  Some funk on the aroma.  Some cherry fruit as well.  Rounded cherry ripple ice cream flavour with some biscuit.  A bit like a sour cherry cheesecake to be honest.  Just a touch boozy to be honest.  Some cherry liquer style flavour on the finish.  Its an odd thing.  Is it a barley wine with some fruit or is it a sour beer with too much sugar and alcohol?  Tasty and makes me drunk.  But the alcohol is just too obvious on the finish.

Poured this beer into a pint glass to drink.  The beer was a cloudy, dark amber-orange color with light, noticeable sediment, and a massive foamy and creamy light tan head that had long-lasting retention and light cling.  The beer had a rich sour cherry aroma with a mixture of caramel malt and earthy hops, along with a floral component.  Its taste was quite flavorful with a very subtle sweet effect, but mostly featured a sour fruity and cherry taste.  The body of the beer was very creamy, rich, and full, with a good level of carbonation with slight fizz and was mostly wet and silky.  Major props to Eric for bringing this quality beer to Peru!

2010 Vintage. When the bottle is first opened, you are immediately hit with this sharp pungency of fresh cherries. This aroma rapidly turns into a bit of a cherry cough syrup type scent, and then once poured the lacto begins to take over with hints of unripe cherries. There is a slight hint of vanilla in there (which Im guessing is from the oak) as well as a nice forest quality, like fresh grass or the inside of a forest on a sunny day.

The taste is quite surprising, especially when compared to the 2008 vintage. Its sour, but only slightly and its sourness is masked by quite a bit of residual sweetness. There is a lot of dark cherry flavored, with some chocolate coming through as well. A bit of harshness comes from the wood and it is still quite boozy. I think that over time this will turn into something beautiful, but for now it is complex but a bit disoriented feeling. It finishes very much like cough syrup and burns for quite some time.

08 vintage on tap at City Beer Store. Poured into a fluted glass.

3.5 A: Opaque amber brown color. Came with a small, frothy beige head. Retention wasnt too great and little lacing was left.

4.0 S: Funky and more tart than sour. Lots of fruitiness with focus on cherry, plum, and maybe some grape and peach as well. Earthy, dank funkiness.

4.5 T: Again, good funky - earthy, sweat sock type funkiness. Lots of cherry, plum, and tangy lactic acid fruitiness. Moderate tannic astringency. Light oak and a decent amount of vanilla.

4.5 M: Medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Pleasantly creamy and super smooth.

4.5 D: Really tasty and certainly good with some age on it. I went back for another glass.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 06-20-2011 03:52:28

2008 bottle thanks to Jcwattsrugger. Pours reddish dark brown. Nose of cheese, sour cherry, vinous oak, funk and basement aromas. Taste is tart and sour cherry, vinous oak, wild yeast, chocolate and funk. Medium body.

Been a couple years since this was consumed.  Have drank fresh and aged at 1.5 years.  Sour cherries, minor notes at funk, and a lovely tender taste into a mixture of pinot and cab.  And I really do mean tender!  Rides right along the sour notes quite well.  Kinda wish we wouldve saved a few more of the original batch!

2010 bottle at SAVOR. Poured an amber color with a small, almost non-existent head. Aroma was sour cherries, fruit notes, alcohol pretty well masked. A huge fan here of this sour wild ale, but probably not for everyone. This one was superb.
Bottle, rudolfs sour tasting. Sherry colored pour. Boozy. Aromas of cherry, orange zest, mild brett. Active pour, higher carbonation. Cherry, citrus zest, wine. Real nice

22 oz bottle. Pours a deep, hazy amber with soapy beige head. Aroma of farmhouse, sour cherries, oak, with subtle cab/sauv notes. Flavor is much the same with a nice acidicness, sour. Mouthfeel is medium body with fizzy carbonation. Over, very enjoyable, complex brew!

2010 bottle courtesy of Sebowski from FBG...thanks.  Pours an amber brown with minimal head.  Smell is extremely strong...cherries, tangerine.   Very drinkable, not actually as sour as I was expecting.  Flavor loses sourness as it sits open.  Not bad at all.

10 bottle. Clear cherry/rust red in the glass with an initially thick, bubbly head giving way to a slight, off-white ring of foam hugging the sides of the glass. Aroma is thinnish light tart, a touch of sour cherry, and a chewy almost fruity licorice/tart through the finish. Taste is cherry/off-tart up front, a muddled sour through the middle, a bit of a malt presence (yikes!) in the back third, before winding down with a light medicinal cherry sour through the finish. Aroma/flavor imprecise and the overall presentation a bit out of whack.

Free samples at Monte Vista Fire Station. Nice tartness in the nose, however it doesnt taste as sour as Id hoped. Straightforward. Some bready and caramelly malts, but they come off a bit dirty at times. Well made.

22 oz waxed bottle purchased a few days ago from the state liquor agency. Pours a crystal clear light ruby red color with small and slightly thin light tan head that dissipates fairly quickly. Aroma is very nice - an undercurrent of light caramel and red grapes, with a notable but not completely overwhelming lactic-type tartness, very vinous complex dark fruit notes, especially tart cherries as well as a touch of pear and apple. Flavor is richly malty, with notes of caramelized apples and cinnamon, lightly toasted oak, tart cherries. Finish is fairly dry but with some residual sweetness. Palate is somewhat thick. Overall this is quite good. The funkyness is done really well in my opinion, and the cherries are definitely present but also not overwheliming. There is a bit of a sweetness in the finish that Im not crazy about, but overall this is really a great beer.

Please note that the bottle warns best drank after 11/1/11, and I do feel this beer would benefit from some age. Amber color, head disappeared quickly. The nose was funky, earthy, with some cherries. Taste was sweet cherry, malty, and slightly acidic. Letting our other bottles cellar.

Bottle.  Tasting at Belmont. .
Dark amber in color.  Has more malt and oak in the aroma than expected.  Flavor is sour and tart with a balance of brett and oak along with strong alcohol.  Finishes dry with a lingering alcohol presence.  Complex and flavorful.

Cloudy ruby pour with eggy-white medium head. Head lingers for a while and leaves nice lacing. Sour raspberry throughout. Light bodied. Clean quick finish.

Nice.

The beer is a watery amber, brown with red highlights. The head is light brown rises about a finger but fades quickly leaving light carbonation on the rim of the glass. The lacing is very weak. 

The aroma is medium in strength, represting some nice sour notes. There are light blackberries, vinegar and oak. Vinegar dominates the most. 

The taste is much to light for my liking. There are very small vinegar and sour notes, but mostly I taste tea. There is an unpleasant funky sour after taste. 

The beer is heavy and full and sticks to your mouth for several seconds.

This is not very drinkable. I could probably drink a bottle if I split it with someone but this would be the last time Id drink this. I would not search this out or recommend getting it unless your a big time sour fan and just want to try it.

On draft at Beer Revolution.  2010 batch.  Pours a reddish amber with a ring of white head around the outside of the glass.  Leaves some small spots of lacing when swirled.  The aroma is very oaky with strong cherries.  A decent amount of vinegar comes through as well as a little bit of red wine, a little bit of mineralness and just a hint of alcohol.  I dont really get any of the funk usually associated with brett.  The initial taste is sweet with some lactic acid which goes into strong oak and cherries, as well as some tannic, red wine.  The finish is very acetic.  Not much alcohol in the taste.  Light bodied.  Medium-low carbonation.  Pretty astringent.  Overall, I was a little disappointed in this beer.  It is really dominated by oak and vinegar.

22oz bottle 10 Reserve (Courtesy of RSRIZZO)-48° in Snifter-Pours a medium ruby red with a small loose white head. Aroma of sourness, tartness, cherries, malt, and dark fruits. Taste of malt, sweetness, yeast, and cherries. This medium bodied brew is well balanced and quite tasty. Great job.

Bottle @ home. 2010 Vintage. Pours a dark cherry red appearance with a creamy tan colored head. Dark sour cherries, Brett, sweet dark brown malts, and a slight wine-like aroma. Dark, slightly sour cherry flavor with a sweet dark malty body, Bretty, lightly carbonated, wine-like flavored body. Slightly strong woody flavor on the finish along with the sour cherries and Brett. Tasty complex beer though I think some of the rough edges might go away with a little aging (especially the slightly alcoholic, woody finish).

2008 bottle shared by smokepot during RBWG 2011 
Appearance: Hazy brown with a medium sized off-white head and good lacing 
Aroma: Fresh dark fruits and apples 
Taste: Fresh fruits, apples, tart cherries and some light sourness 
Very nice.

Fiery orange-red body, thin clumping light beige head. Active carbonation. Sour nose with tart fruit and pineapple. Puckering sour, funky body with pineapple and wheat, in addition to brown sugar and toast. Also some wet socks funk, though not predominant. Quite good.

22 oz bottle, thanks to a trade with Daknole, served in a tulip.  Pour is an orange highlighted mahogany with three fingers of quickly dissipating, off-white head.  Nose is sour cherries, brettanomyces, wet pavement, light funk, light wood, and some oddly spritzy odor, almost like vinegar, but with none of the unpleasing aspects.  Taste is tart cherries and a spritzy sweet/sour combo, which is absolutely delicious.  This partially fades and the body defines itself as a semi-dry red wine.  This lingers as a slightly tart, sour cherry cabernet for quite a spell after the swallow is finished.  I must say this sour is out of this world! Every aspect is kept in perfect harmony so that the tartness, sours, and cherries do not overstep their boundaries.  All this combined in a wine like pallet that is second to none Ive sampled.  Bravo Dechutes!

Bottle. Pour is copper red color with a tiny bubbly head that dissipates to a thin collar. Aroma is funky sour cherries. Taste is sour cherries with a funky aftertaste. Palate is thin and fizzy with a dry finish. This is a pretty easy drinker four being a sour. I really enjoyed this!

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2015 17th April 2009 Clear red brown beer. Crisp palate. Sour brown beer. Nicely balanced. Not overly sour with its sweetening alcohol in the finish. 3.31st July 2015Tropical Croydonia Bottleshare. Hazy amber beer, no head. Palate is light and semi dry with a very fine crispness.  Light malt cream. Savoury flavours in to a light vinegary sourness. Jammy fruits which are overtaken by mild geuezey wet wood. Light savoury finish. Not bad at all.

2008 bottle from brewolf...thanks Michael! - Pours ruby red amber with a small bubbly tan head. Not terribly pungent aroma--light cherry and balsamic vinegar, with some maltiness to give it a nice base. Taste is vinegar and sour cherries, citrus rind, a bit of lactose. Dry and not too tart. Smooth and velvety carbonation--nicely balanced. Nothing is overstated in this beer...nice!

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2014 2012 bottle poured a murky reddish brown. Very little head. Aroma is yeast, cherries, raisin and oak. Taste is cherries and tart acidic flavors reminiscent of red wine. Lots of sour and yeast funk toward the finish. A little alcohol burn at the end blend well with the sour. This is one of the best of the style.

2010 bottle, 10.5 percent, best after 11/01/11, maybe my other bottle can make it past that date but not this one. Pours dark hazy reddish brown with some sediment. Aroma of mild cherry, oak, yeast spiciness, some herby funk. Taste is great, not very acidic and sour, lots of fruit sweetness, earthy. Very nice, it will be awesome to see how this develops.

From notes:

Pours a deep, dark ruby red/chestnut brown with mahogany edges and and a frothy 1.5 finger off-white head. Decent retention, slowly fading into a lasting ring. Minimal splotches of lacing left behind.

Wonderful earthy oak aroma with a subtle hint of vinegar as well as hits of tart cherry, dark berries, oak and vanilla.

Medium bodied with slightly funky tartness. Puckering but not too much so with no acidity. Its more sweet really with lots of vinous dark fruit. Hints of grape, dark cherry, raisin and plum. Well balanced with earthy oak and a prominent vanilla character. Complex, well balanced and very quaffable.

Really a beautiful appearing beer, with all sorts of browns and reds in there along with an off-white head. Smelled great too, with tartness, funk from the wild yeast, some earthy tones, and different berries (including cherries) prevalent. The taste was good, but after having a couple of Russian River sours (which were also brewed with Brett), I think this could have been better. Sour start is not as cleanly tart as I would have liked, and it didnt meld fantastically with the cherries that came next. However, overall it did taste quite good, with the earth and booze going well together. Had an average palate feel. Will re-rate if get a chance to taste an aged bottle.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2012 2010 bottle- May 30th 2011.  This is great!  Brett nose.  Smooth mild cherry tart berry red wine taste.
Had  a dry finish.  Dont know what eles to say.  Love it!  Dont drink it too cold.  Would like to add that a noticable amount of alcohol is present, amost in a boozy way.
  2012 bottle.  Great stuff!  Has wood in the aromas.  Still burns in the finish.

Slightly hazy orange/red pour with some sediment visible, egg shell white head with good retention.  Mouth watering.  Aroma hit my nose about two seconds after popping the cap, definitely has the wild yeast funk, tart red fruit, wood, one sweet tart, subtle vinous character, smells delicious!  Nice sour flavor on the palate, medium body, soft-tingly carbonation, alcohol is very well hidden (2010 vintage is 10.5%).  Finishes with the feeling that Ive just snacked on sour cherries and a glass of pinot noir.  I really enjoyed this one.

Had this in the bottle when it first came out but I like it way better on tap.  Ruby brown color, beige head.  Sweet and sour nose; vinegar with sugar.  Complex taste.  Tastes like a tart hard fruit candy with damp wood. Highly acidic bit good.  Sourness and numbing alcohol linger on the palate.  Nice, nice beer

bottle shared by silphium. thanks! cherry red pour with medium white head. sourness, must, horse blanket, cheese and lemon all over in this beer. the flavor is more sweet than the nose, with a bigger citric and herbal aspect as well. good stuff

22oz bottle, 2010 release. Im still not sure I like being patronized by label descriptions. How much of this beer are they really selling to people who dont know what it is? Anywho, pours a dark red color with a small head that dissipates after a minute or two. Fruity aroma with a touch of cherry and some dry woody character. A little rotting/overripe fruit in there. Lacking much noticeable brett character, though is does have a light acidity that clashes a little oddly with the bitterness and strong alcohol flavors. Medium bodied and warming in the finish. Cherry flavor never really comes out. Boozy with some acidity and a off fruity character are about all I pulled out of this by the end. After recently having the keeping beer from Rodenbach, which is similar is strength and concept, this just looks really mediocre all around. At 5-6% it at least would have been drinkable, even if lacking good flavors for the style. Definitely not worth purchasing again.

Lucky find while on vacation in Redondo Beach,CA. The pour is dark ruby red with no foam. Carbonation is present, but very minimal. Cherries and citrus in the aroma. Has a good amount of that sour funk in the flavor, but nothing too over the top. Very smooth and easily drinkable. A truly incredible sour!!

22oz bottle.  Pours a clear red amber with a thin creamy off white head that leaves some lacing.

The aroma is acidic and tart, slightly sweet, cherries.  

The flavor is acidic and sweet cherries with a bitter, musty, slightly medicinal aftertaste.  The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with smooth carbonation.

Overall, its a solid fruity sour.  Id prefer a little more sour or brett and less of the weird aftertaste.

Red orange brown in color... Sour gueze aroma... Flavor is oaky, interesting blend of sweet and sour.... Kinda watery mouthfeel and finish is kinda skunky, like rotten apricots...  If you want a good sour, go to Belgium or Russian river...

22oz bottle.  Body is a nice amber with red hues and an off-white head.  Aroma is fruity and a bit sweet, but the sourness comes through.  Flavor is similar; the cherries come through nicely.  The sourness is not overdone, but definitely shines through.  A nice oak flavor comes through on the finish.  Quite simply, this is a wonderful beer.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2011 Pours carbonated translucent blood orange with orange tinged head that immediately disappears. Aroma is citrusy, fruity - lemon/lime, grapefruit and cherry. Distinct cherry flavor with lemon zest and a touch of vanilla in the flavors. Definitely a sour ale.  If you enjoy tart fruit beers I think youll thoroughly enjoy this.

2010 Version: Bottle pours red-brown with very little head.  Aroma shows spicy cherry with ginger, menthol, and a touch of funk. Flavor shows the same with additional notes of oak and vanilla.  Somewhat sweet and only lightly tart at this point.

2010 Tap: Much better currently.  Acidity seems much more developed and the integration is coming along.

I love this beer so much its hard to put it into words. The 2008 release was one of the first "sour" brews Ive ever had and I was hooked. Drank the last 2008 bottle I had the other night. Currently sipping the 2010 release. Fantastic! Sour aroma to begin which is met with sweetness thats honestly cherry. No funk in the nose. First flavor is amaretto followed with almonds then straight into the tart cherries and sourness that lingers perfectly. This is probably one of the most perfect brews I have ever tasted. Thank You, Deschutes. Cheers!

Bottle.  Clear dark reddish brown pour, very little carbonation and a good aroma of very tart sour cherries.  Flavor is medicinal alcohol and cherry, slightly creamy/malty mouthfeel and finished boozy.  Decent beer, but I was expecting much more based on the previous ratings.  Will probably try to pick up another bottle and see if cellaring helps.

Draft. Sampled on 12/10/10 at Pracna on Main. Poured into a tall pils glass a clear copper amber color with very little head. Aroma is that of  sour cherries and slight acidic notes, very minimal aroma with some sweetness. Medium mouthfeel with slight carbonation. Slightly boozy. Cherry taste with white wine characteristics. Woody. The Brett is pretty subdued, may be interesting how time treats this. Easy drinking but with all the craziness over this in MN, Im really note sure if it deserves the hype.

Tap @ Brewforia: 2010 batch - Amber, brown color.  Aroma of alcohol, apples and woodiness.  Didnt really notice cherries in aroma or taste.  Flavors of bitter apple, paper and alcohol.  I liked it quite a bit, but honestly was expecting more.

2010 edition Draught..  Poured clear red.  Looked like a glass of wine. Aroma is cherries and oak, lots of cherries and oak.  Sour cherry flavour with more oak,  Lots of alcohol flavour at all times.  Unpleasant finish.  At times, I couldnt decide if this is a bad beer, or a good cherry wine.  Sip it,
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text:
UPDATED: AUG 22, 2013 8/22/13 rating: Red wax-dipped bomber, 2012 vintage, stamped "Best After 8/20/13." Pours mostly a clear pretty amber with a medium beige head with good retention. Aroma is strong in vinegar, dark fruit (cherries, definitely--the flesh and the pits), molasses, wood, dusty basements, barnyard funk, caramel, booze, raisins. Taste is mostly sour (8/10 on sour scale) with a lingering dry bitter/savory finish; alcohol is strong but not overbearing. Mouthfeel is creamy, body full, carbonation somewhat soft. Boy, were they right when they said to wait on this one. The first time I rated it, I had a fresh bottle and it was pretty horrible. What an improvement a year in the cellar does to this! 9,4,8,5,17=4.3

Initial 12/4/10 rating: Bomber poured into snifter. 2010 vintage. This bottle reads 10.5% ABV. Pours orangeish-brown with a medium head that collapses fairly quick, leaving a collar of foam full of big bubbles. Aroma is flowery, pungent-funky, molasses, tart fruit (cherries? apples?), brussell sprouts. Taste is sweet and sour (quite unlike the tart explosion found in New Belgiums La Folie, which I drank before this) with an alcoholic bite. Flavor is a bit wine-like. I taste raisins. Harsh. Carbonation is medium-high, mouthfeel is both creamy and oily, body is full, finish is looooooong. Hard to drink. 7,3,4,4,8=2.6
(22oz bottle).  Pours orange-copper color with off-white head. Aroma of funk, grape, vinegar.  Taste is sour, but there is a sweetness in the background.  Medium bodied. I really like this beer.

Bomber. Clear ruby brown with nice tan head. Aroma is cherry leather with funk sour all around, medium booze, malt balls. Taste is dark berry sour all funky that comes at our tongue in a rush, ending quickly but burning lasting long boozy as it goes down. Huge nose. huge burn.

2010 bottle. Pours a clear amber (virtually see through) with a small light tan head until it disappears into rings around the glass rim. The nose is slight cherry, cherry pit, lemon zest, Brett, slight vinegar, and alcohol. Taste is slight muted tart cherry, slight lemon, big Brett yeast, slight alcohol, slight vinegar, and a little bit of citrus hops (muted). Mouthfeel is dry like champagne at the end after a creamy initial mouthfeel. Pretty good but not nearly as sour as I thought it would be.

2010 version. Split with the wife - who picked it up for me at $10.99 at local beerstore (all sold out in a day). Wine like nose, Golden amber color with minimal head.  Softly tart with oaky wine barrel, sour cherries, and a bit of brett funkiness on the palate. Similar in taste to the Deschutes St  Ryans - which had some extra brett flavors.  Fruits come out as it warms up.. Cant say that it is as tart as the previous version or as sour to me. So, while muted, still a very nice cherry flavored finish. Well done and refreshing. Even the wife liked it, - so that is saying something....

Consumed in September 2009.

Pours a dark ruby with a large white head. The smell is one of sweetness with a little bit of tart fruit coming in, mostly cherries. Hints of wood. Some slightly-roasted malt and accompanying sweetness. The taste is most prominent in the tart fruit department, with a bit of an alcohol bite. The mouthfeel is medium with a good amount of carbonation.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-04-2009

Schooner @ Naked City. A little tarter than I would have liked, but man, oh man, what a beer. Served a bit too chilled to get a good whiff, this ale hit all the high notes for me. Gorgeous ruby red, playfully sweet with a cherry tartness I couldnt resist. Fairly fantastic.

2010 Batch from Bottle
Appearance:  Pours a deep auburn with a fluffy beige head that subsides to nothing within minutes of entering the glass.

Aroma: Tart cherry, pie filling and light chlorine.

Taste: Bitter fruit pit (cherry or peach), funky vinegar and tart cherry.

Mouthfeel: Juicy, puckering with modest levels of carbonation.

Overall:  Really good,not very sour, but decent levels of funk, and very tasty.  The bottle suggests not opening this for an entire year. I couldnt wait.

Bottle shared by Sean, thanks! Poured a hazy amber orange with a light gray head that dissipated to the edges. Aroma was full of tart cherries with a bit of acid and a slight sweet grain backing. Flavor was similar with a really nice tart cherry note, some acid and light sweet grain coming out in the finish. Quite drinkable.

Jar fill from Uber Tavern. Ok, so the draught version has more alcohol than the bottle? Newer version i.e., not the 2008, but the 2010. Brown, ruby appearance. Not much head on this thing; actually, there wasnt any head at all. Wow, this beer is pungent -- cherries, brett, and some red wine barrels are coming through. Damn, this thing is pungent, considering that Ive let this warm up quite a bit. Very big sour cherry funkiness to this. A little bit of brett pops through. Its not so much mouth-puckering tart as much as it is fruity. This does have a very nice slippery, oily texture. For a sour brew, this has the perfect texture, at this point. A nice woody flavor pokes through, and the brett compliments this. Damn, drinking this warmer than usual makes this an awesome sour. Nice tart cherry flavor. I want a bottle of this, but I must say, the draught version is better.

2008 bottle through trade poured an orange brown in color with a covering of white foam. aroma has funky earthy yeast, sour cherry, mild balsamic acidity, and a little sweetness. mouth feel is light and there is light carbonation. flavor has a bit of thick cherry, brett, dark fruit sweetness, light acidity, red wine tannins, and dry barrel wood. this is definitely more fruit and malt forward and has a bit of sweetness so it throws me a bit as far as being a flanders brown.

On tap at the brewpub in Portland. Dulled yet thick cherries, brett, mildly sour with a fresh feel. The cherries are sweet and soothing withnithing to strong as this takes on a mellow approach. Watery cherry taste, earthy chewiness, light funk, here and there I can taste the alc. Fruitcake, molasses? Something like that. Feels ok but nothing special, a bit thick. Should have eaten before pounding that back. Oh well. Gonna be a mess by 4.
Poured dark reddish amber brown, wood, cherries, vinegar, malty, little grapefruit.

Bottle at Marks Sour Tasting on 06/16/2010. Clear copper body with a small off-white head. Vineagar and dark malt aroma with some fruit. Sweet fruit falvor, vineagar, tart and funk. Medium body with moderate carbonation.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2012 08 bottle. Pours reddish brown with a medium fizzy orange head. The aroma is bretty with cherries, lemon, leather, oak, and a hint of malt sweetness. The flavor is sweet up front with a complex layer of fruitiness. The balsamic like astringency is balanced nicely with a hint of molasses like sweetness. Sweet and sour comes to mind. I imagine the age has added an additional layer of complexity as it tastes slightly more funky than expected. Overall, a really nice beer that will satisfy any sourhead, yet not clobber your palate. I cant wait for the new release!

2012 vintage tasted on 11/23/12. It pours a dark amber color with a small, fizzy off white head. It retains at about 3/4 inch. The aroma is really inviting with a quick burst of sour cherry, raisins, brown sugar, hints of red wine vinegar. Smells nice. The flavor is very rich and tart with raisins, plums, sour cherries, brown sugar and a little wood aged vinegar in the finish. Not a lot of funk, just a lot of dark fruity maltiness balanced perfectly with a good amount of tart/acetic acid to give it some kick. The mouthfeel is much bigger than I remember...probably because of the boost in gravity this year. The finish has a lot of woodiness and salty leather. Wow. I really love this vintage. Its almost turning into a sour quad or something like that. Total Score: 4.2

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2010 Medium amber pour.  Funky, slightly woody, sour lemon and fruit nose.  This tastes moderately sour with a little balsamic sweetness at the start, develops funk and herbal character near the finish.  Pleasant and approachable.

Red-amber, decent head. Feintly tart nose, with impressions of wheat. Easy tart flavor, fairly mild and balanced. As far as sours go, this is pretty mellow and quaffable, but its hard for me to tease out much complexity.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2010 shared bomber thanks to bhensonb.  The Dissident pours a deep red / brown with a 1 finger off white head.  Huge sour aromas burst from the bottle after cutting the wax off and popping the cap.  Once in the glass, aromas of wood, light funk, cherries and lacto fill the nose.  Medium body with more oak, tart cherries and a solid level of sourness throughout.  The Dissident combines a wonderful sour base with a sweetness brought on by the cherries that adds another layer to the already complex and intriguing wine notes from the pinot and cab barrels.  Strong tart finish with more oak, cherry and Brett.

Bottle courtesy of Bockyhorsey. Murky/dirty reddish/brown. Minimal head. Aroma is rather subtle, faint vinegar and cherry and not much else. sour cherry character shows up a little more in the flavor, but again, not much going on. Oily/slick mouthfeel.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2010 Courtesy of Styles
Bottle:   The aroma consists light sour cherry, yeast, alcohol, and a hint of mustiness.  It pours a cloudy brownish-orange with a yellow tinged off-white head.  The flavor starts with some light sweet cherry and caramel.  The finish has some light sour cherry notes with a hint of oak.  Medium bodied with mild carbonation and a soft mouthfeel.

Yet another rating that seems to have disappeared from the system. Pours a very dark crimson red color and topped by a small, foamy tan colored head that shows good retention and leaves some lines of lace around the glass. The aroma shows a good dose of soured cherries, oak laden vanilla, vinous pinot grapes, and some dryness from the wild brett yeast. The flavor follows suit with the sour cherries and woody oak coming through strong followed by hints of the vinous grapes, vanilla, and some floral hop bitterness. The cherries add a nice tartness to the flavor profile while the brett yeast seems to dry things out on the palate. Medium to full bodied on the mouthfeel, dry and tart with ample carbonation. The sour cherries linger on the finish. This is a great beer, and am glad I have another bottle to see how one does with some age on it.

No head, colour of cognac. Very fruity, cherries on alcohol, faint Brett-like notes. Quite dry, yet very fruity flavour, wood, but no real acidity. Character of a Flemish Oud bruin with cherries, rather than anything lambic-related. Sharpish MF, gives the impression of being quite carbonated whilst looking utterly flat. Special one, not undeserving of serious attention. One of the better Deschutes tries.

Pours deep red, almost brown, with a minimal tan head.  Nose is classic sour ale.  Vinegar and grapes are most apparent.  Flavor largely matches the nose I suppose.  Good, refreshing sour bite.  This sour reminds me a lot of the Rodenbach Grand Cru, though Im not sure I like it quite as much.  Either way, fantastic beer.

Pours clear red with fluffy white head, aroma is big fruit with cherry, grapes, sour apple.  Taste is some big tart cherry, vinous, with a sharp acidic middle finishing dry and balanced.  Not mouth puckering but good sour and fruit mix.

Surprisingly, Ive had this 08 many times but have never rated it, so here goes! Colour... cloudy copper-amber with a thin head. Nose... loads of acetic acid and hints of papier mache. Palate... decidedly tart, notably bitter, lightly acetic, with bits of cherry bark (yes, Ive tasted cherry bark) and skins and a moderately long finish.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2010 It might be starting to thin out a bit, but this beer is still quite good.  Lots of fruit - sour cherries and berries.  Some vinegar and acid.  Medium sour.  Soft feel.  A very good beer, though not quite up to the best of this wonderful style.  9/4/8/4/15

Edit: 2010 version.  Draft.  Very good, again.  Much more funky oak flavor than I remember from the last batch.  Very woody dry.  Sort of a cheesy flavor.  Sour cherries are delicious and dont overwhelm.  Refined and complex.  Full mouthfeel.  The mouthfeel of Dissident is noticeably best from a fresh keg, in my opinion.  Not too sour yet.  9/4/8/5/15

bottle.  pours a nice abmber color with golden orange highlights.  Smells of vinegar with slight cherry.  Sour cherry taste but limited depth - thin.  Not overly acidic nor fruity,  Easy to drink and ejoyable.  Great bottle look.

Appearance: A crisp mahogany without much murkyness. 1 finger cream colored head quickly dissipates to nothingness.

Smell: Very lively and enticing mix of grapes, oak, cherries, and some vinegar. Not as sour or as vinegar like as other oud bruins which leads me to thinking it will be quite drinkable.

Taste: Not as complex as the nose and my suspicion about the high drinkability is accurate. The fruitlike qualities of cherries, grapes, and red wine meet some butter cream, salt and vinegar and are presented in a well balanced mix. Aftertaste is minimal for the style. I was hoping for more from the wild yeast they boast about using on the bottle. The taste has many less dimensions than the smell.

Mouthfeel: Mildly dry, medium body for the style, low carbonation.

Drinkability: Extremely high for the style and for a 9% alcohol brew.

This is an outstanding American attempt at an Oud Bruin. Its well balanced and toned down compared to some of the more extreme examples of this style. If bold is what you are looking for you will be disappointed.

Ive ordered 2 more bottles from Bottle Trek and am glad I did. My thoughts were to cellar them but the brew is already so drinkable and smooth that I dont think additional aging would enhance this brew.

9/27/09 REVIEW: 1 YEAR LATER TO THE DAY

I decided to crack open my last Dissident today and when I looked up my initial review I was surprised to see that I had written it exactly one year ago!

Appearance and smell are the same as a year ago. The flavor hasnt improved at all. If anything the yeast is the same to slightly more pronounced. Mouthfeel is getting a touch thinner. I liked it a touch better fresh. Id say drink em now if you still have em.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-27-2008

Quite brown in colour. Wow, sour! This packs a sour punch that on the first sip makes your face screw up. Not a beer for the fainthearted or the un-initiated. I could imagine drinking this on a hot summer day with prawns off the bbq.

A: The pour is a dark amber/copper color with a minimal off-white head that has minimal retention.

S: A mild vinegary aroma as you might expect from a Flanders Red/Brown, along with a bit of oak and a mix of sour cherries and malty sweetness.

T: The cherry flavor is more pronounced and provides a balance of sweet and tartness. The vinegar character is moderate and overall the beer is not that sour for the style, nor is the oak all that present.

M: The body is medium with a smooth and somewhat light carbonation.

D: Not my favorite Flemish sour, but a decent representation. Only lightly sour, but a decent balance of sweetness and tartness.
Overall pretty solid and enjoyable.  Lives up to the description well and lends to the flanders style favorably.  Definitely a must try for all you sour heads.

22oz bottle shared with friends

This is the beer that paved the way for my interest in sours.  Vinegar aroma with notes of oak and cherries.  Nice tartness and a yummy aftertaste.  This is a really good beer.

22 oz. bottle shared by shawnm213 at DLD 10- thanks again, Shawn!  Pours a nice cloudy brown color with plum-red highlights and a small tan head.  Aroma of tart fruits like cherry and apple, wood, funky yeast, chocolate, and some floral notes.  The flavor hits pretty much the same notes as the aroma.  Medium-bodied, with mild carbonation and a sour, woody mouthfeel.  Glad I got to try this one, as its a pretty cool beer.

Bottle I got in a trade. Thanks!!

A- Dark murky cedar colored body that pours with a 2-3 finger or so off-white head. Head eventually fades to a thick collar and has great retention from there. Some lacing is left behind in the glass. Body is somewhat translucent but the red light still shines through pretty well

S-Vinegar comes to the nose first followed by a metallic presence. Underneath this is additional sourness, oak, cherry and a yeasty funk. Its right on for the style-but maybe a little too metallic.

T-Upfront the oak and cherries really come through well and underneath is a slightly sour funk typical of the style of any Belgian brown. Some more sourness comes through for the finish-this sourness is more acidic than vinegarlike and is light to moderate in strength. What lingers on the palate is a slight acidic sourness, oak, a hint of cherry and a very slight metallc presence.

P- Wonderful. Light to medium carbonation and a smooth slightly yeasty body.

O- This is a very good beer. Much milder than other sours I have experienced recently. The oak and cherry are really the main characters for this brew. A well done brew by Deschutes and I look forward to trying others (have the Abyss 08 in my cellar).

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-25-2009 01:40:49

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2011 Received bottles from hopdog and 3/4.  2008 bottle Still have on in closet.  Shared one at DLD with some dudes.    Nice soft funky cherry, fruit, chocolate.   Moderate tartness.   Great beer.  very refreshing and tasty.   Boat load of wood character, which i liked  a great deal.  4.0.


Rerateee...   2010 bottle from big silk.  medical and bandied cherry doughy chocolate sourness.   Touch of bile.   Moderate cherry sourness.  Good not great.  3.6.

Taster at the Veritas 007 release. Thank you random guy.  A hazy deep red beer with a thin white head. The aroma is sweet with notes of malt, fruit, and berries. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and berries, moderate tart finish. Lacking a bit in the traditional flanders tartness. Overall not bad.
2008 bottle..Cloudy brown orange with no head...Aroma is barnyard, horse blanket and brett, very funky... Flavor is sour with a woody note..tons of carbonation..good.
Pours a clear deep red with some head. Aroma of malt vinegar. Mild sour black cherry flavor that is also somewhat sweet. Nice hop finish.  Damn tasty.

Bottle. [thank you after4ever]
Pours completely clear red with a small, creamy, off-white head. Aroma has caramel malts, light berries, flowers, liqourice, light apple zest. And a wonderful underlying tartness. Medium carbonation, nice creamy and dry mouthfeel. Flavour is pleasantly tart, fennel, dry, apple. Long, lingering, dry tartness. Really one of the best sour ales Ive had from America.

On tap at Churchills.  Pours a muddy orange with off-white head.  Fruit, pear, cherries, malt, light caramel, wood, and finish with a bit of sour pucker.  Really I am disappointed, not as good as I was hoping.  Not that sour, more emphasis on malt and fruit.  Very glad to try it though.
