Reddish brown colour, small off-white foamy head. Aroma is sour wood, some tart fruityness as well as mild maltyness as well. Flavour is sour and tart fruits and wood along with some caramel. Very pleasantly balanced. Mild spicyness also after it warmed up a bit. Hides the ABV very well.

22 oz. bottle shared by shigadeyo.  Pours a deep reddish copper color with a medium sized fizzy white head.  The nose is cherry fruitiness that is both sweet and sour at the same time.  Some underlying malt sweetness and mild oak are there as well.  The flavor is sweet caramel maltiness, oaky, lightly toasted, earthy, dry red wine with a more subtle tart cherry quality than the nose.  There is a slight funk that I would expect to increase with age.  This was very drinkable when we tasted it because the acidity, funk, etc. were not fully developed.  Finish is smooth and somewhat dry.
( 22oz bomber of 2008 vintage thanks to BA javib458) Pours red-brown with nice tan head. Nose of cherry, oak, and vinegar. Taste of cherries, oak, and light vinegar.

22 ounce bottle courtesy of Sparky27. Thanks! Pours a lightly hazy red color with a thin head. Good head retention and lacing,. Aroma is tart and sour with notes of berries, cherries. Taste is very similar... raspberries, cherries, cranberries, some sugary notes. Medium bodied. Very nice.
Pours a reddish orange. Slick texture. medium sweetness, rather bitter and acidic, but drinkable. Sour fruit and some floral notes. Enjoyed.
22 oz.  This beer suprised me.  I planned on it being good.  It ended up being very good.  A nice tartness actually made it refreshing even though the high alcohol content.

Bottle courtesy of thirdeye11.

Pours brown with an off-white head. The aroma is a mix of vinegar and very tart cherries. Definitely a very good aroma. The flavor is also heavy on the cherries with some funk as well. It is definitely a sour beer, but not as sour as the aroma led me to believe it would be. You also get some oak and vanilla in the flavor. Medium to high carbonation and very drinkable.

08 bottle. Pours a ruby brown with a smallish, off-white head. Aroma is slightly skunky, but very good - cherries, apple cider, a tiny bit of caramel, some grassiness, some lemon. Flavor is just a bit tart, but also very dry. I keep thinking its going to be sweet, but the sweetness is nearly completely countered by the dry, grassy, almost (but not quite) hoppy note. Really tasty, and another great effort from Deschutes.

Deschutes Brewery--the dissident Flanders Style Brown Ale Reserve--2008 Release--22 oz. Bottle.  9.00% ABV--30 IBUs  4.0 / 5.0  Brown Ale--Belgian.	Thin fizzy mild lace tan head.  Light sediment.  Clear bright dark cherry red color. Mild hop sour fruit ester front. Wild yeast. Doughy sour sweet mild toffee cocoa mellow fruit malty body. Dry sour citrus mild hop cloying toffee end.  Sampled 10/3/2009	2 @ $10.99 each.

bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  amber/ruby with a white head.  lightly tart, dried fruits and orange peels on the nose.  nice on the palate with some flavors that are pretty much dead on with the nose but not as tart as i was hoping for.

Bottle courtesy of thirdeye11. Hazy orange colored. Gentle sour aroma. A fair amount  of cologne. A nice smell. Flavor of tart fruit with some strawberry finishings. An interesting take on the sour.  Would probably age well.

Amber colored, nice head and lacing.  The aroma was not good, but I can  hold my nose to drink this beauty.  Lots of tart cherry, loads of sour brett which tried to take my tongue and fold it in half.   Some sour vinegar notes made me think this was a cross between a lambic and a flemish sour.  Tough to drink, but still enjoyable....a sipper for sure.

22oz bottle cellared at least 1 year.  aroma is burinng hot sour/tart note of shoes, socks and BO.  strong rotten white wine.  awesome head retention and burnished amber color, huge nucleation -- this bottle gushed as predicted by my mate gonzoillini right on cue, begging to escape the confines of its container.  the ultimate treat is the crunchy candi end, ultra dry -- typically found only in unblended lambics and near perfect geuze.  big raspberry flavor comes to the table and bends your facial expression with its sourness that begins to delve into club soda and then tonic water with its wild, uncontrollable dryness.  perhaps the nearest perfect beer i will ever sample.

Draught @ Brouwers Café:   Heavy reddish amber, moderate to large foamy light sandy colored head, nice lacing, lively carbonation.    Reminds me of a lighter version of Duchess.   Faint oak on the nose, slightly sweet, slightly sour.   Weird, almost reminds me of a lighter Duchess on the nose.   Not as cloying or sweet, perhaps a bit more dry.   This is better than I expected.   Yeah, Duchess light, not as sweet, more oak, a bit more dry.   Average body and mouthfeel.   About what I expected.   A little bubbley otherwise.   Well balanced, not over the top on any aspect.   Alcohol is well hidden, but does feel a bit warming.   As it warms up it picks up more of a cherry flavor.   Okay, this one is growing on me.   For an American brewer to do this, great job!   Glad I have a few bottles to put down.

Bomber from Nbutler. Pours reddish brown with off-white to tan head. Aroma is sour cherries, wood, vanilla, and some light caramel. Flavor was tart with sour cherries, vanilla, caramel and some wood. Found that the tartness of the beer increased as it warmed. Thicker mouthfeel for a sour. Downed almost the whole bomber myself as my friends I shared the bottle with did not really care for the whole sour beer experience.

Bottle thanks to dimier.  Pour is slightly hazy dark copper with a small tan head.  Aroma is woody, light wood, cranberry, light rose hips, and faint cherry.  Flavor is woody, effervescent, lightly acidic, faint cherry and strawberry.  The finish is woody for sure, but eventually finished lean.  This is solid, but I would like more tartness.

Finally got through the the double wax layer on this 2008 traded bottle to pour a cloudy brown beer with ruby highlights. Just a thin tan head but nice carbonation. The aroma is so strong of sour cherries that my mouth honestly waters before tasting (a little blue cheese too). Very balanced flavour that does not overpower you with sour. Flavours of: cherries, vanilla, oak and some alcohol in the finish. Really enjoyable sour that was exceptional with dark chocolate as dessert.
My kind of sour.   Not overwhelming.  Sour with vanilla, oak and definite alcohol.  Slightly cloudy amber with a small head.

Wow, this was so amazing. My first sour beer. Didnt know what to make of that first swig, took me by surprise, didnt like it at all. but then i sat down and worked on it, and boy did it grow on me!

Bottle thanks to dmac. Pours a amber color with a little head to it. Has a sour cherry smell to it. Has a cherry taste that is a little sweet that goes to a sour. Its not sour as I thought it was going to be by the smell. There is also a little oak in there as well.

Bottle. Pours a reddish amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity tart aroma. Smooth and slightly tart fruity malty flavor with some hints of caramel. Has a fruity tart waeming finish with a slighlty sour aftertaste.

22oz bottle thanks to Andrew.  Pours a murky red.  Sweet and tart notes.  The vanilla and doughy malts are hidden underneath the sour fruits.  Cherries, red fruit, and citrus flavors are sour with that distinct brett notes.  The acidic sour fruit with the brett wasnt my favorite combination.  This might be better with a different strain of brett or souring with flanders yeast instead.  That said, not a bad beer.
22oz, pours hazed amber. Nose of vanilla, sour oak cherry, and caramel. Fl is sour cherry, oak, vanilla, with acidic notes. Thin body, a nice sessionable sour!

Mild sour ale, brown in colour with a small beige head. Fairly straight forward bretty thing with light subdued fruity notes. Mildly sour and easy going with flavours of brownish malts, brett and light barrel.

Thanks to Dr. Bill for having this at his tasting. 
This is a complex beer whose tangy & vinous notes make it very enjoyable.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2011 2008 bottle. beautiful ruby red body with a reasonably thin head. wonderful sour aroma dominated by cherries and slightly acidic. not as sour as i remember and finishes pretty dry. this one may be past its prime, or i may not have cellared it correctly. still really good with a very dry finish, nearly wine like. still one of my favorite beers of all time

Deep brownish red with a rather small tanned head that actually stays on for a while before settling. Some lacings.

The smell is quite interesting. There is a prominent mix of tart vinegar and clean brett aromas going on with notes of really funky barnyard, cherry tannins, red wine-like grapes, grass, yeast and wet wood. Hints of oaky vanilla. A complex smell, but slightly too edgy.

The taste is not as complex nor as interesting as the smell would have you to believe. Its actually quite sweet with prominent malty flavors of caramel coupled with pleasant tart fruit aromas (cherries and grapes). Complementary, somewhat clean, brett aromas and notes of mud, oak, grass and vanilla. Hints of yeast. The finish has a mild bitterness to it, brett, sweetish alcohol and dry cherry notes. I think it would have benefited from less alcohol flavors.

Medium, almost full body, and medium carbonation which is not how I want a Flanders Oud bruin to be - I prefer them with more carbonation. Its actually almost smooth and sticky.

A fairly good attempt at a style that seems hard to master outside of the boarders of Belgium. Its slightly too heavy and big to be really good. The additions from the cherries are really nice though.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

Picked up bottles at a gas station in Sequim. Go figure. Not as crazy sour as a Duchesse, but more drinkable. A llittle woody, a little brown sugar. If youre a sour fan, this is a "must try" on your list.

A sourness that makes my jaw hurt is rare but this one did it. Color is a dark ruby red with a nice off white head. Mostly wild yeast aroma with a little bit of woodiness. Flavor is subtley complex and very wine like. Apart from the obvious sourness there is some nice fruit flavors mainly cherry. The added cherry fruit is noticeable. Wine like characteristics in the texture and fruitiness. Earthiness from the yeast adds another dimension. Finish leaves a touch of sweetness. Very interesting and well done. I would love to try this with a little bit of age on it.

Thin tan head. Clear amber brown color. Fruity aroma, cherries, cinnamony and lightly tart and woody. Body is med/light with a soft carbonation, lightly oily. Light woody flavors, vinous notes cherries and spices, lightly earthy, doughy and malty. Easy drinkin tartness, light sourness. Nicely done!

2008 Reserve.  Pours a clear, bright, dark red-orange-brown with a fine, medium-dense light tan head.  Soft, tart aroma with wood and a pleasant "barnyard" brett aroma along with fallen orchard fruit, rich, fresh-pressed apple cider, and a hint of hops spice--very autumnal.  Flavor is sour with a soft toasty caramel malt aspect.  A restrained tart red fruit character evolves from the sourness combined with subtle woodiness and some oxidatiion in the finish.  Very good, but only moderate complexity for a beer with these characteristics. (Perhaps it could benefit from some more bottle age?)  Their is good weight and balance in the body but the only drawback is a bit of rawness left on the roof of the mouth.

Bottle from Jake65.  Pours a brownish-amber color with foam patches floating around on top.  As soon as the bottle is cracked I get a very pleasant aroma, currant, berries, brett and a little bit of a lighter citrusy scent.  Flavors are tart and sour but not extreme.  Lively carbonation.  I keep thinking wild berries as Im drinking this with some funk and wood-paper notes.  This can compete with other top tier dark sours like Consecration.  My first beer from Deschutes, this was fantastic.  Thanks Jake!

2009 GABF, Friday session.  Oh yes this is good, and I had this one behind the stages, not sure if it was poured at the stand.  Pours dark brown with almost no head.  Aroma is quite tart, grainy, with notes of dark ripe cherry.  Flavor is robust, tart cherries and plums with dark chocolate and wood.  Very well balanced, with a delicious lingering after taste.  Body is smooth with perfect amount of weight to it.  I want a bottle of this!

Deep red/pink pour with a 1 finger frothy head; really nice looking brew. Aroma is extremely strong, caught a whiff right after opening the bottle. Notes of red wine, funk, yeast, and sour cherry are predominant , and the lightest bit of spice, perhaps clove, mixes in there as well. The flavor starts with tons of fruit, notably cherry, black currant, and a bit of dark fruit. This seamlessly weaves into the funk that comprises the middle section of the flavor. The finish goes back to a sweeter note, and I think this is where the red wine notes hit. Palate is very drinkable, but the sour sweetness sticks to the tongue exquisitely, and the 9% is absurdly well hidden. Not quite as robust as Cantillons Saint Lamvinus, but definitely reminds me of that, at least in terms of a broader genre. Excellent brew- looking forward to having more of Deschutes offerings.

Brownish grapefruit hue wiith an excellently proportioned tight frothy off white head. Aroma is quite vinous with cabernet and brettanomyces coming through powerfully. A yeasty dough note rounds out with some sour cherries in a swirling torrent of aromas. Flavor starts off fruity and defined with sour cherry and black currant being most notable. The excellently proportioned brett funk and hay follows closely behind, as does red wine grapes and the most subtle of tannins. Sweet considering the style- not attenuated to near the extent of some of its counterparts, though it works excellently here. Funk is quite up front, though vinegar is absent. Palate is medium to full with a slippery, smacking finish. Im very impressed.

Bottle shared by JW77...thanks!  Pours a nice brown color with a tan head that leaves some good lace.  Funky aroma full of cherries, brett, wet hay and sweetarts.  Flavor is tangy, funky, lemon, and maybe some red wine notes.  Damn good.

This 2008 reserve wax capped bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a large sized head of foamy finely sized light brown colored bubbles that were and left behind a transparent softly carbonated red brown colored body. The weak aroma was brown malt Irish Red malty and sour. The crisp mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The mild flavor contained notes of brown malt sour and mild nut. A decent one that I would consider having again.

Deep jewel-like ruby color with a thin, quickly disappating head.  Very deep velvety nose of sour cherry, musty horse blanket and Brett.  Some cherry flavors, rhubarb, old raspberry Jolly Ranchers, and funky mold.  There is something vaguely forbidding about this beer but somehow desirable.  I hate to say it, but I am starting to like some sour beers.

2008 edition bottle via and shared with oakbluff. Amber in colour with spritzy carbonation. Wonderfully complex aromas of farmhouse funk, pale malts, lemon, apricot, and a bit of wood. Sout lemon. Quite sour in the mouth with lots more lemon, funk, and soft mozzarella cheese. Refreshing and quite dry on the palate. Not overly fruity or vinegary, which is nice for me. This is some classy stuff indeed!
Dark reddish with small head.  Fruity, mash style aroma, medium body with lively carbonation. sweet sour with some bitterness.
poured a burnt ruby orange. Nose was vinegary with a strong cinnamon smell. Taste was disappointing, some vinegar, some brown sugar, but pretty thin and inharmonious.

Pours a nice brown with a foamy head that disappears quickly. 

Smells great, funky sour cherry lemon goodness. 

Tastes of funk and Brett. Very light oak and fruit hints. Similar to a less fruity red poppy. More apple comes out as it warms. There is no trace of the alcohol content. 

Mouth is medium in body and carbonation.

An excellent drink and dare I say my favorite from
Deschutes this far.

[2411-20090801] Bottle. Sweet vegetal chewy-like malt aroma. Hazy, dark orange red body with a medium-lasting foamy white head. Mildly spicy flavour continues with the chewy fruit malt. Medium body. Interesting bitter but not to my tastes today, or it could be that I just had a crappy spicy beer beforehand that was still lingering on my tongue. Would try this again anyway.
(w/ others @ BCTC; Cooperstown, NY)

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2013 2013-03-09. Crisp dark red amber, small beige head. 3++ Interesting aroma is fruity, lightly funky and tangy. Mild woody touches, muted cherries and cherry pits. 7+ Flavour is fairly dry, cherry up front, light wood throughout grows in the finish.  Average palate, very light carbonation gives it a dilute wine like character. Pairs intriguingly well with the hazelnut salami. 7/3/7/3/16 Bottle shared by Wilco  "Where do you get all these meats?!?"
2009-08-01. Orange amber body with a modest beige head. (3+) Aroma has modest sour funk, touches of lemon. (7+) Flavour is modestly sour, light funk, non-specific sour fruit character that I can not place. Muted wood notes. (7+) Average palate is lightly carbonated. Interesting.  8/4/7/3/16 Bottle at BCTC

I didnt expect this style to come out of Deschutes and quite honestly did not think they could pull it off, but I was wrong and I am impressed.  This has a great deal of pucker power.  Very clean for the style, with some solid wood tannins and some acidic sour fruits, green apple skins and sour cherries are what first comes to mind when I think of the tang that is happening on my tongue at the moment.  Nicely done and I would like to see how this one lays down.

Sour vinegar and sharp wood tannins, this beer is aging nicely.  Soft clear tawny, small head.  Apple cider, green apple skin, wine grapes and pie cherries.  Thin in body but rich in character.  Brett is coming through nicely in a dry and cottony sort of way.

22 oz bottle, 2008.  Hazy reddish brown with foamy beige coating.  Nose is mild sour cherry, funky wood and strawberry preserves.  Creamy mouthfeel with a soft tang.  Taste is cherry, caramel, vanilla and cola.  Dry, airy finish.  Juicy, lightly sour, very nice.

Bottle shared by shigadeyo.

Poured a clear reddish brown color with an average frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate to heavy sour tart fruit aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy sour & sweet flavor with a medium to heavy sweet & sour finish of moderate to long  duration.

This is a standout beer.

22 oz bottle courtesy of several possible people.. But well give the shout out to mreusch on this one! Thanks, Matt! Pours a murky rusty iced tea hue, reddish sunset works in with decent beige head, dense, dies to a small layer. Aromas smack from a decent distance away: oak, cherries, a touch of sweet malts beat out by vanilla and dry champagnesque feel. Deeper inspection shows more cherry, oak, slight vinegar, and a light sweetness of caramel and vanilla. Initial is a nice tartness, cherry and vanilla follow suit with caramel malts, oaky qualities, dryness, a fairly lively body. Well carbonated, mellower than the aroma originally led me to believe. Finish is tart cherries, dry oakiness, and a very mellow sweetness. Sour finish and tart lactic qualities remain on the palate, touch of soft cheese and sweet malt. Overall, a pretty good sour.. Tamer yet still strong as the sour grows as a wave does.. Stronger as you go on, very very nice.

Scored a 22oz bottle of this via trade.  This style (Flanders brown) has been growing on me in recent months.  Pours a hazy, translucent, amber, reddish brown with a faint, ringing white head.  Aroma is excellent, fruity, floral, funky, red grapes, apples, pears, some light wood, slightly sour.  Flavor is well balanced for something so odd; sweet and sour, apples, tart cherries, lemons, wood, flowers, honey/pollen, grapefruits, butterscotch.  In small sips the caramel malts come through nicely with an enveloping sweetness.  Finish is tart, slightly buttery.  I loved every drop of this, for what its worth my girlfriend did too.

bottled, pours red/amber with medium tan head, aroma of sour cherries with the slightest sweet malt notes, amazingly fruity sour taste with lingering citrus on palate, no alcohol notes in taste, delicious

Pours a ruddy brown with a fleeting off-white head.
Funky tart aroma that reminds me of rotting apples.
Tart, yet balanced by an underlying sweetness.
Smooth

A Mes rate. Bottle at home thanks to MJ. A lovely dark amber colour. No head but still a very attractive beer. Really fruity, nice barrel notes some faint framboise and a lovely tartness at the back of the throat. Very drinkable. An almost puckery sourness and an all round great blend of wood and fruit. Quite chewy for the style. Framboise and kriek notes in the solid, clean finish. Booze is well hidden but the belly warmth gives it away. Jolly enjoyable and a little under rated if you ask me.

2008 Reserve - Flanders Style Brown Ale
7/02/2009:  The Dissident has a deep honey color with big bubbles and a thin bubbly crown.  Sweet perfume fills the aroma.  It is also slightly tart and acidic.  As far as flavor goes, it is yeasty with chewy caramel in the front.  It has a nice slightly sour cherry characteristic and a good, lasting finish that has a tartness that sticks in the back of the throat.  This beer is slightly thick and sticky, but is well-balanced overall.

1 pint 6 fluid ounce wax-sealed bottle (234 08 1724 / 9% Alc. by Vol.) from bitbucket.  Thanks Bob!  Rating #245 for this beer.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2009 Beer number seven in a killer July 09 Super Secret Sour State Line Tasting (SSSSLT) featuring (first to last by my counts): Supplication, Consecration, La Folie, Dissident, Cuvee de Castleton, Red Poppy, Lambic de Hill, Festina Lente, Panil. Poured a brownish reddish color with a nice little off-white colored head. The aroma was soft red/brown Flemish Sour type malts: cherries and some caramel, yeast. The flavor followed, dry cherries, very faint sour notes, full malt bill, Barley and bready notes throughout. Mildly sweet, a gourmet Duchesse (my cheap thrill, sugar-pop "sour ale"), done really nicely, but not an over-the-top pucker factor. Really freaking awesome. Thanks, Steve, a great one.
Re-rate, bottle from Bockyhorsey, Dec. 2009: Again, a very consistent experience, I blindly echoed a lot of the same stuff as I drank this. Maybe some brown sugar in the nice rich malt base, very balanced and complementary sourness. So good. Bready, brown sugar, and rich rich cherries in the malty base. Fantastic. Digging this stuff. Thanks, Bill, for yet another shot at this one.

22 oz bottle

Thanks to a generous trader for sending this my way.  Now that I am catching up on my backlog I have time to get my rating in.  As with the Abyss I hope that this sees regular release cycles and is not just a special one-off test batch.  If so I may just have to buy another bottle despite the thick wax seal.

Aroma / Appearance - The thin beige head is supported by a ruby tinged body which glows under light.  Murky lacing completes a picture perfect setting.  Sour cherries and topioca pudding laced with cinnamon, and red hot remind me of a sour brown that someone has spiked with red hots.

Flavor / Palate - Dried sourdough bread, chocolate, and chili powder fill every corner of the palate.  Very drinkable despite its 9% ABV content, this is fluid as it travels down the throat.  The sour finish is not tart enough to upset the stomach but does clear out any bugs that may be lingering in the stomach.  Im not sure what this costs but if it is anything less than $14.99 a bomber its worth buying at least once.

Bottle shared with Savvy1982. Pours a hazy orange with a small white head that forms a ring of pearls around the edge of my snifter. The aroma has brett all over the place. Peach, raspberries, band-aids, citrus rind, cherries, floral notes and bretty sourness on the nose as well. The sourness rolls across the tongue in waves, I really like that. Sour cherries, raspberries, peach, band-aid, biscuit, pencil shavings, plums, and horse blanket. Mouth feel is what I would expect from this style. Very complex drinkable beer. I really enjoyed this one!
Aroma just doesnt live up to the smell unfortunately.  Its a decent sour, but it just seemed so promising.

Bottle, with huge thanks to Bitbucket for the trade. Pours a hazy reddish-brown, with no head to speak of, just a thin ring. Nose is Brett, horseblanket, tight apples, acid, mild raspberry/cherry aromas, some perfume in the upper reaches of the nose. Plenty of well aged red wine character in the nose as well, shades of old Bordeaux. Flavors of apples, nice tart sourness, great balance, no discernible booze at all, a bit of band-aid / medicine character, but this is the only real fault in the palate. Biscuits, sweet raspberry, tannins come out as the beer warms. Pencil shavings, red licorice, and more red wine character. So very nice!
Another old rating.  Aroma was sweet and sour. Noticed some cherry flavor coming through. Nice light tartness. Pretty easy to drink sour beer with a bigger body than most.

Bottle sampled on 10/25/08 courtesy of Axilla: Pours a transparent copper orange with a thin, wispy-lacing white head.  Aroma of lightly sweet toasty biscuity pale malt and a light oaky tart balance.  Body starts with good fullness and sweet caramel and oaky tart character toward a drier finish.  Well-balanced and enjoyable.

Big thanks to MrBunn for sharing this! Brown in color, thin dissipating head.  Aroma of cherries and a light wine note.  Light alcohol noticed along with the cherries and a bit of apples with the noticeable Brett. Has a weird funk that lingers around the edges.  Goooood stuff.

Bottle (750 ml). Pours slightly hazy reddish-brown with a small off-white head that leaves nice lacing. Aroma is tart fruit and berries, a bit sweet but noticeably acidic as well, with some more subdued malt and spices. Flavor is similar, a quite smooth mixture of sweetness and tartness with mainly berry flavors, with malt in the background and a little vinous and woody character. Very good.

Bottle with thanks to boutip.  Body is a slightly orangish brown with a little bit of a film of small bubbles on the surface.  Aromas are a little odd... A bit of pie cherries and some rust or iron or something.  Flavor has a bit of that metal/medicinal edge to it, but is still pleasant enough.  Fruity sourness is well developed, and were it of for the odd metally edginess, this would be truely outstanding.  The metal seemed to die back as it aired and warmed, so you might want to try that for a bit.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle from Bleeng at the Houston sour tasting.  Thanks, man!  Pours a thin iced tea brown with a winey plastic cedar nose.  Flavor is perfumed cedar and bread dough.  Tingly but average mouthfeel.  Eh, could be better.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Bottle 1pt. 6fl.oz. @ [ Thisted tasting ].[ Courtesy of Maria ]. Clear medium red amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy malty, caramel, sour berry, wood. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and ligh to moderate sour with a average to long duration. Body is medium to light, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20090316]

Hazy deep amber with a medium beige head. Sour aroma with vinegar, sour berries, wood and lacto. Leather and  wood in the flavour along with sour cherries, vinegar, lacto and brett notes. Finished sour. I like.
Bottle thanks to BMan1113VR. Amber red in color with an average sized off-white head. Aroma is tart with funk, apple, pear and perfume. Taste is sour, funky with hints of hay, apple and earth.

On tap at Brouwers SourFest.  Pours a beautifully clear bold red with very light head.  Fantastic sour citrus aroma.  Little sour on the palate, with nice bitter hops undertones.  Overall, a bit too sour for me, but nice clean finish, and a very drinkable beer.

Bottle thanks to mes, at mess gaff with harry. Alroudn rating: Fruity cherry/framboise(why did i use english and french?), tart, woody sourness, carbonation is good. Its an american sour, but a good one.

Bottle, courtesy sebletitje. Dark red pour, bubble white head, bubbly lacing. Sour nose, crap load of piney cherries, dry earthiness, raspberries, some cider. Big tart cherries in the flavor, chalky notes, dry grain, crisp apple cider, some tartness throughout. Medium-bodied, balanced and drinkable.

Bottle (750ml).  At MesandSims, London May 10 2009). Clear brownish-amber with an average frothy head.  Smells great - funky, slight sour with sweet light roast malt and dry floral bitterness - a bit boozy.  The taste is a touch lemony-tart, I got a zing of tangerine zest off the top, but it settles down and is ultimately pungently floral, with a nice sweet/sour balance to the malt.  Fairly light-bodied, syrupy and acidic mouthfeel, maybe a little under-carbonated.  Still, lovely and sticky, a good funky brew, if a tad boozy.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2009 Amber brown color with not much head. Aroma is sweet/tart with cherry and some wood. A little funk with the sweetness keep it balanced. Taste is smooth and tart with cherry and plums and grape skin. Very good.

Pours reddish golden brown with plenty of bubbles rising and a beige 1/8 inch head.  Tart aromas of sour apple, berries and cherries.  Slightly funky taste is wonderfully sour with apples, cherries, and the taste of the dust off sour patch kids.  Can really taste the grape.  Excellent sour.

Bottle 65 cl. Courtesy of KimJohansen. Slightly hazy amber golden with an off-white head. Lightly tart, woody aroma. medium body, tart wood, sweetish brown sugar. Somewhat astringent sulpur. Finishes tart. 010509

2008 bottle.  Pour is a fairly clear, ruby color with a beige, fairly small, pillowy head which settles quickly to a very small froth and leaves some lace rings.  Nose is nice with tart notes of overripe and black cherries, light horseblanket funk, wet hay, earthy undertones, and faint oak and vanilla.  Flavor starts out sweeter than I thought with vanilla and caramels but the overripe black cherries soon dominate with a more than moderate acidic tartness.  Other notes include light oak, wet hay, and faint hints of bretty funk.  Palate is very lively, prickly, velvety, light to medium; a bit thin.  Finishes fairly long with the tartness remaining throughout, black cherries, light vanilla, oak, and some wet hay with just hints of funk.  Everything was in perfect balance, sweetness, light bitterness, moderate tartness, and funky and fruity notes.  Not one of the most complex beers, which was a bit surprising, the flavors worked well together.  A nice sour brown and certainly a well hidden alcohol content; very drinkable at 9%.

Bottle at RnH Drink for Charity.  Thanks to everyone who brought great beer to this.  Pale reddish with ring head.  Funky sour cherry wood aroma.  Sour cherries wood funky acidic flavors with very tart finish.  Nice effervescent carbo.  Very nice.
Bottle thanks to bman1113vr.  The look is clear, amber colored, and has an off white head.  The smell is sour, fruits, funk, horsey, and alcohol.  The taste is fruits, taste, sour, funk. Good.

Bottle at the Drink for Charity event at Rattle & Hum. Pours a very lightly hazed brown with a thin white head.  Smells really nice with some cork, sour funk, and hay on the nose.  Nice tart sourness, with a touch of fruity plums or currants.  Finishes a touch hot, with almost something off.  Started really strong, but ended a bit weak.

Bottled. A hazy deep red beer with a thin white head. The aroma is sweet with notes of malt, fruit, and berries. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and berries, but also with and acidity and some lacto basilicus, leading to a tart finish. The body is thin.

Bomber. Pour is ruby/brown with small off white head. Aromas of sour cherries, tart funk, and gummy bears. Flavor is tart with cherries, carbonation, and a acedic finish. Nice brew with the 9% hidden wonderfuly.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text:
#22 at papsø blindtasting
cloudy amber, small white head.
aroma is sourish, and sweet honey, in gen3eral okay sourlsh.
flavor is sourish with a strange flavor i dont like, citrus. palate is a bit thin.

Bottle #22 at Papsøs blindtasting.
Cloudy orange coloured with a small off white head.
Fruity and light acidic aroma of wood and rubber with notes of spices.
Fruity and light acidic flavour of wood, berries and hops.
Tart and hoppy finish.

#22
Bottle. [Papsoe grand American tasting] Light bubbly beige head that mostly diminished. Spare display of lacework. Cloudy amber color. Aroma of rubber, sour overripe fruit, citrus, leather, soap, vinegar. Medium bodied with an average carbonation. Moderated sweet and acidic flavor. Lingering sour overripe fruity finish. 7 / 3 / 6 / 3 / 14 = 3.2

From bottle, Papsoes blindtasting #22. Pours hazy deep amber to light brown with a small off-white head. Light fruity and acetone like aroma. Sweet and fruity with a light acetone note. Acidic and fruity flavoured into a sour and subdued sweet finish.

22oz bottle thanks to BrewDad. Pours a ruby color with a large white foamy head. A really awesome nose of sweet cherries, malts and lots of sourness, wood and sour cherries. The flavor is similar; light acidic sourness, cherries, funky brett, malts, light chocolates. Awesome. No alcohol noticed at all. Very drinkable. I love this style when done this well.

On Tap at Baileys Taproom in PDX.

The color is an brownish red with a very light head. The lacing that this beer leaves on the glass is just amazing... It smells of very sweet fruits and slight sourness. The taste is extremely tart raspberries and sour apple. Dissident has a very thin light body which makes it extremely easy to drink. I truly enjoyed this gem.

copper pour with a white head.  Lots of spice,  perfume,  and brown sugar in the aroma.  Flavor was up front cherry,  gym socks,  more brown sugar,  and plenty of odd spices.  Lightly sour finish,  no real hint of the abv.  Good amount of carbonation.
bottle thanks to bman1113vr.  poured a cloudy amber with an off white head.  aroma of tart cherry.  flavor was tart cherry, smoke, and some bitterness.  medium body with low carbonation.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2011 Thanks sebletitje for the share.  Pours a copper/ red with an off-white head.  Nose is funk, brett, sour, vinegar, funk, and some fruitiness.  I also get light hints of vanilla that are quickly checked by the brett.  Flavor is tart and some berry with notions of becoming more sour than anything else.  Lots of vinegar and some other stuff that runs away.  I agree with sebletitje, and like it more that Belle Prox.  Definite brett presence, but the sour, vinegar and cherries still come through.  Medium-bodied and pretty good overall.

courtesy of BA trader.
2008 bottle.
Pours copper / ruby with white head.
Aroma fruity, sour, vinegary.
Taste, light tartness, cherry, strong sour wine like fruits, light notes of wood barrel, finish is of wood and sour.

Not usually a fan of sours, but this one easily beats Isabelle Proximus.

bottle courtesy of sebletitje. pours a medium red with a white head. aroma is funk, brett, sweet fruit and sourness. flavor is a nice tart, barnyard, fruity, vinegary goodness. Earthy, oily mouthfeel. Many thanks for pulling this one out late night style.

Courtesy of sebletitje. Pours clear copper with tan head. The aroma is cherry and Brett like tartness and really not much else. The flavor explodes with an initial turbulent tartness and then easing toward modest berry sweetness and a bit of sugar malts. The experience then heads in the direction of even more tartness than before and in the process burying any remaining islands of fruity berry sweetness. I didnt pick up anything in the way of wood notes. This puppy quickly becomes too tart for me and begins to taste like ass . . . ok well, aspirin anyway.

Bottle thanks to Trevor211! Fiery ruby-amber color, nice fluffy beige head. Nose of cranberry, grape juice, minor vinegar, a little stable. Flavor is more complex and quite diverse, but not very coherent: fruit juice, vinegar, alcohol, and wood lead the way. Very smooth, fruity body, again like you are drinking juice. Overall pretty interesting stuff. I like the cranberry notes, reminds me of New Glarus Raspberry Tart and Ommegang Rouge, but this not very sour nor is it very cohesive. The varied flavor is in fact a little conflicted and slightly off-putting.

Bomber poured a clear reddish amber with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of sour cherry, vinegar, oak, earthiness and light carmel. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry tart finish. Flavors of sour cherry, light carmel, vinegar, light earthiness and a hint of oak with a crisp dry lingering tart finish. Beats Duchess any day!

(Bottle thanks mybestfriend) Pours reddish brown with a small pale nougat colored head. The aroma is light to medium acidic and light to medium sweet with tones of vinegar, light barnyard/basement brett, light vanilla-ish oak, dry apple/pear cider and tart cherries. Malt brings light caramel, nuts and toast. The flavour is light to medium sweet, light to medium and light bitter. Tones of vinegar, dry apple cider, some citrus, light barnyard, earth, light caramel and light nuts. The mouthfeel is medium round, light syrupy and light to medium carbonated. Earthy and vinegar finish Medium bodied.

Not sure why this didnt show up under Deschutes, but whatever.  Bottle is from PUBN.  Pours turbid ruddy muddy brownish with off-white head. Nose is tart fruit, earthy, sour mashy malt, some merlot.  Tastes tart, with eartyy cherry and berry, plus merloty red winey notes, and well hidden alcohol.  Yet another great beer from these guys.
bottle, thanks to bman1113vr, ruby coloerd with some foam, aromas of sweet raspberry and strawberry, flavors of rose petal, sour cherry, strawberry jam
Bottle thanks to bman1113vr. Ruby pour with a small head. Pleasant sourness in the aroma. Taste was sour cherries, caramel and bread. Syrupy mouthfeel

Bottle via a trade with mashmaster. Pours with a small, off-white head over a hazed brown body. Aroma of plums, chocolate and alcohol. Taste is slightly metallic, with sweetness, dark fruits, and sourness. Light carbonation. True to the oud-bruin styles meatiness.

22ozer. Aroma of cherries, merlot, raisins with a slight earthiness. Clear reddish brown with a quick dissipating bubbly head. The sourness hits the back of your mouth first, there is a layer of sweetness that comes on but is taken away by a sour finish. Medium body with a somewhat thin mouth feel, lively carbonated and a long sour finish. This is my first sour ale so Im not sure what to compare it to, but this is a superb ale. The sourness grows on you and the sweetness starts to come out as you drink it. There are lots of different flavors and sensations going on with this beer, almost a carnival for your mouth.

pours a light murky tan/tawny/red colour, with a light head .. . sour cherries and pure sour goodness ... super smooth, and lip smacking! .. . sweet/sour playing on my tongue, really indescribable goodness here .. . The nicest sour yet!! god i wish i had more!!

bomber thanks to bleeng.  Shared at the March Houston Tasting.  Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Nose of sour fruit and malt.  Taste of sour fruit and malt and vinegar.  Mouthfeel is medium and creamy.  Not as sour as many others.

In short: A funky, sour and very acidic ale that is also very sweet (caramel, maraschino cherries) and overly tannic.  An Intense sipper better in small servings.
How: Bottle 22oz, was-top.  2008 batch (first one).  Consumed when about 6 months of age.  Sent to me by Oakbluff.  Thank-you so very much Scott.
The look: Beautiful red-brown-amber body topped by a medium beige head with low retention
In long: The nose is moderately wild with a sweet maraschino cherries.  Taste is surprisingly caramelized.  Caramelized malts, oak, maraschino cherries, a lot of earth, some vinegar.  Very heavy, especially for the style.  I dont think Ive ever had a sour ale that was so sweet while remaining very sour and very acidic. The beer is extremely astringent, too much so.  A strong sensation of red wine tannins and thats where the beer lost its appeal to me.  Far from highly drinkable.  The high average score of this beer can only be due to people sharing bottles.  So tannins/puckery sensation is so strong that it me about 30 minutes to go through my bomber.  Its a Dissident alright, it did not go down without giving a strong opposition.

I had some of this at a tasting. It followed three other fruit beers. There is definitly a fruit taste to this one but unlike the other beers previous to this one, this one had more of a hops flavor to it. Quite enjoyable.

Thisted tasting. Courtesy of After4ever, thanks Tom. It is a very beautiful red-brown beer with a creamy head. The aroma is sourish/fruity with notes of malt and berries. Te flavour is sourish and slightly sweet with light notes of vinegar, malt, caramel, berries, fruit and light horse blanket. It is a very well balanced and nice sour.

Bottle - Still new to the sours and this was one of my first, and after trying a few I wanted to rate this one again.  Great flavors of cherries, and slight undertones of oak and red wine. Not that tart, but enough to let you know the brett is there. Overall a great sour, and if you are just trying this style out, a great place to start b/c it is pretty mild and very easy drinking.

Bottle shared at stateline.. Thanks to tytoanderso for sending this one to me a while back... Ruby red in color, not much head. Tart aroma with some fruits. Taste is close to the nose, tart, with some fruityness. Probably the most enjoyable sour beer I have had to date.. Light/medium texture, super easy to drink. Overall, this beer really impressed me and is one of my favorite Pearl Jam songs!! Which has nothing to do with the beer.....  Thanks ty!

22oz bomber shared with Pineypower, thanks Dean. Murky brown body with a small slick of off white head that quickly and totally disipates. Funky tart aroma of sour cherries and vinegar. Earthy flavor which is comprised of cherry and vinegar. Rather full bodied for a sour with a good dose of carbonation and an almost creamy finish. The individual components of this beer are good but overall its just to earthy and thick or it could have rated higher.
GABF 2008. Amber pour with tan head. Aroma is wine, dusty cherries and some apples. Flavor is tart cherries, vinegar and slight sourness, but less than what I was expecting.

Bottle 2008. Pours out a cloudy slightly reddish tinged brown with a small lacing off white head. Aroma is vinous with some wood, cherries and some funky yeast notes. Taste is complex with a nice sourness, cherries, earthy notes and a nice brett tartness, slight alcohol in there, very smooth for 9%. Well done.
Pours a hazy brown.  Yeasty aroma.  Taste is leather, barnyard, sour cherry, raisin.  Nice mild tartness.
08 bomber shows ruddy brown color with blonde halo. From medium bodied malty base comes raisin paste, tart cherry and oak sour without alcohol warmth or hop bitterness.

Bottle.   Pours a murky brown color with a thin soapy off white head.    Aroma is oaky, tart cherry, vanilla, light funk.   Flavor is oak, vanilla, light funk, caramel.   Palate is medium bodied, medium carbonation, finished tart and and bitter.   Nice stuff, reminiscent of JP LaRoja and NG Enigma.

Bomber. Pours dark orange, hazy with a nice full white head. Nose is amazing: citrus, tartness, funk, acid,  bretty-full of flavor. Taste is very tart and tangy, bitter and dry, a bit sweet with some grapefruit. Brett is here but only adds, does not dominate. Full, rich, evervescent body. As good as many Russian River sours.  Well done.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: poured reddish, not too thick. An aroma of spit and bacteria. Initially, the sourness well controlled by malt. AVerage mouthfeel. Drinkable over a meal, tastes somewhat of a wild ale that builds up in the mouth over repeated sips.Intersting.

Double wax dip Bottle (what a pain) Pours out a murky amber with red highs topped with a small ring tan head. Aroma was of berrie, sweetness and some of the 9%. Tast was more of the berrie but lots of bitterness at the end like grapefruit peel. A little tart. Not to bad.

Bottle. Body-Dark iced tea with a thick ring of bubbles. Nose-sour, woody, light funk, cherry, toothpicks. Taste-brown ale, little tart, dry, sharp bite on the back end that isnt from the funk, sour cherries, dry wood, lots of tannins, straw, hay. A very nice mild sour.

Brown with dissipating tan head. Aroma is of tart cherries, caramel. Flavor is the same plus some tart apple. Acidic, tart, slightly bitter with some sweetness at the end.  The alcohol is well hidden. Very good, but could be more balanced. I would like a bit more malt flavor.

Bottle that was handed over in a trade in NYC Nov 08 from the marvellous Miketd consumed 27-02-09, cheers Mike youre a solid gold star  Pours brown with a bit of reddiness, head is white. Aroma is sour, some tart cherries, warm wet woodland and even a bit of porcini mushrooms steeped in hot water. Mmmmmhhh flavour is lovely, bit woody, nice sourness though not to tangy. At times I reminded of Rodenbach and even Suffolk Strong, woodiness is top of the list on taste but there is a deecent fruity sourness. I could happily drink this all night, great beer.  A8 A4 F8 P4 OV16   4.1

Bottle: Poured a deep reddish color ale with large foamy head with great retention and great lacing.  Aroma of oak and tart notes are clearly dominant with some light funk also discernable. Taste is also dominated by some oak notes with a tart taste with some lactic funky sour notes also noticeable. Good body with great carbonation with no apparent alcohol. While I really enjoyed the sourness and the oak notes I thought the funky yeast didnt integrated that well with the rest of the flavors. Still very good nonetheless.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2014 "this one was fun. i had it at a beer tasting party, and although there were a few others that people didnt totally agree on, this one was polarizing. it was like democrats & republicans in there. our host, who spit his out, was in the "hate it" crowd, while i was on the opposite end of the spectrum. i have even more respect for Deschutes for creating a beer like this. It pours a ruby brown color and youre immediately hit with a complex aroma of musty apples &/or cherries, with so many other things underneath, I cant describe. The flavor is a wonder. more of the same. tart, complex beyond my expectations with a great finish. this beer stands on its own incredibly well or would bring out the flavor in numerous foods. HIGHLY recomended!!! One of the most unique beers Ive had."
Still a hightly rated elegant sour, but complexity has never been the same since the first release (4.7)...4.4 or so since.
(sample from enniskillen and irishboy)clear red with a light brown head.light funk in the aroma with some caramel.flavor is much of the same with some brown sugar thrown in.

Bomber the Chevron station in Port Angeles WA. Nose of caramel, light Horseblanket, and toffee. Clesr rusty brown with a small offwhite, glass lacing head. Flavor was very lightly tart and horse blanket, caramel, and toffee. Tasty but not a very sour ale!

22oz bottle $8.99. I poured this into a snifter and put on Pearl Jam (because I am corny and the namesake of this beer is a good song). Clear, ruby red which seems odd but then I am no expert on flanders reds or oud bruins. First whiff gave off burnt rubber but quickly moved on to a lightly sour vinegar aroma with cherries with the rubber still darting in from the back and a slight touch of alcohol. Nice sour flavors of cherries, just enough to make my mouth slightly pucker but nothing like Supplication or La Folie sour, much more muted and that rubber makes a brief appearance in the flavor. I actually wanted to like this more but I have had too many good sours this year and I am not sure I could taste any hint of wood and the rubber aromas and flavors were off-putting. This is not hard to drink however and does get better as it warms (like most beers).

update 10/12/08
The second bottle contains no rubber and tastes/smells better. Maybe because I drank some Isabelle just prior?

Thanks to fogdog for this beer!  Pours reddish brown with orangy highlights.  Aroma is fairly subtle for the style, but I welcome the lack of sour assault.  Oak, dust, cherries, some amount of mustard and vinegar, and hints of the caramel malt foundation.  Taste is malty and sour, but not as sweet as some.  Cherries, sour fruit, big oak, mustard, light vinegar and a bit of caramel, almonds and bread.  Finishes fairly bitter, oaky, dry and cobwebby.  Im not the worlds biggest sour beer fan, some the effortless creamy palate really won me over.  Smooth and silky, big, but without much weight, and so so rounded.  Just the right hint of heat, but its mild.  This is a real treat, a lovely sour ale for those who want something a bit between Goudenband and La Folie, but with a bigger and silkier body than either.

Poured a golder amber color with an off-white head.  The aroma was just how I like it.  Tart with big leathery notes.  Mildly tart, as in less than the aroma would have led me to believe.  Earthy leather notes.  Light to medium body.

Bottle. Dark amber and mainly clear. Mild subtle Brett and other organisms. Soft, low, flat carbonation and silky mouthfeel. Nice and mellow. Lots of fruit pits, natural seed bitterness, mainly cherry pits. One to get to know.

Hazy reddish-orange.  Raw nose is woody, very fruity and slightly balsamic.  Livelly body has a fruity, funky taste.  Its a dynamic brew that way...it has a lot of potential but I think Id prefer more tartness.

Bottle. Brown colored with a hint of reddish/gold.  Aroma is sour cherry with earthy tones.  Sour fruit up front taste followed by a woody/nutty taste that leaves a lingering tingle.  Not quite as sour as I was hoping for.
reddish brown with tiny white head.  aroma is very sour and fruity.  the flavor isnt very fruity, but still sour and acidic.  it tastes kind of woody.

Bottle and shared with tjthresh (I think I got this from Jon, not sure but thanks anywho): Bronze hued with a small fizzy head and spotty lace, when the worst part of the beer is the appearance you know you got a winner. The aroma is tart cherry and red grape, lacto acid, earthy, some caramel, woody oak chips, hints of grains of paradise as well. The taste has a nice moderate fruity snap supported by light spice and a backbone of sweet malts. Nutty note lead towards the woody barrel influenced finish. The mouth feel is dry yet mouth watering refreshing. Very well done and quite to style of an Oud Bruin IMO. Mikey Likey and wants another.

Courtesy darkguardian.  Pours a very lightly hazy, dark crimson color.  A frothy, well-retained head of tan foam leaves sticky arches of lacing on the glass.  The nose shows elements I never thought I would encounter in a brew of this type.  The requisite sour cherry and oaky vanilla is there, along with some tannic grape notes, but unexpected scents of powdered sugar candy (Necco wafers!) and spicy candied ginger are a real treat.  Flavors arent quite as adventurous, as the sour cherry and aggressive, woody oak take over.  Floral hopping is surprisingly substantial for the style.  Medium-full, tart, and dry, the palate is satisfying.  Sour cherry and vanilla linger on the finish.  Great beer.
Yum!  Earthy and sour with a vanilla/citrus finish that delightfully drips with wooden character.

text: UPDATED: FEB 9, 2009 On tap at City Beer Store, then later a bottle at Toronado.  Well done sour ale.  Reddish-brown color with an off-white head. Aroma of fruit and some brettanomyces. Flavor is complex with strong cherries, brett, caramel malts - sweet and sour at the same time.  Very smooth palate.  Pretty drinkable for what it is.
Crushed with Jakebra.  Belgian brown/sour eh?  Quite sour, fruity nose.  Flavor is the same with a great tart finish.  A damn fine whatever-style-it-happens-to-be.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2009 Powerful yet smooth sour brown ale.  Nose is of dark cherries, raisins, figs, plums, toffee and chocolate.  Medium bodied and mouth filling, with a tart and slightly tannic aspect to it.  Flavors similar to the nose, but  slightly more wood, earth and slight toast and caramel.  Not overtly farmhouse or barnyard, the brett flavor is subdued, but the sourness and cherries pervade.

Purchased 22-oz bottle from Liquidsolutions.biz. Pours a hazy reddish copper sour ale with a thin off-white head that slowly dissipates to a fine film top. Aroma of Brett, yeast funk, some black cherry, light brownish malt, and some cinnamon. Taste is medium bodied, plenty of tartness with flavors of Brett yeast, sour red berries, a hint of vanilla and some barnyard funk. Finish continues the tart berry aftertaste with plenty of dry yeast.

Bottle courtesy of beerbill.  Many thanks.  Deep garnet pour.  Aroma is softly sweet with a light cherry sweetness.  Softly vineous with a very soft lactic tartness.  A really rich cherry note and a bit of light balsamic character as well.  Rich cherry/berryish aroma that accents the soft tartness.  Soft cherry and light berryish fruit with a lovely balance of fruit and lean pale malt.  Light funky aroma and a bit of sweetness as well.  Pretty solid brew.  More Flemish Red than Flemish brown to me, but either way, its pretty nice.

2008 Vintage 22 oz. bottle courtesy of bvc.  This bottle is double wax sealed, which is interesting.  Aroma of acidic black cherry fruit and oak woodiness right off the bat.  Behind that is boozy grainy maltiness.   The Brett yeastiness is present, though certainly in the background.  Overall, a nice balanced nose.  Taste is black cherry tartness with the oak booziness.  The sour funk is present as a liner around the overall taste experience.  Nice melding, though the alcohol is pretty bright.  Palate is smooth and silky, medium and really drinkable.  This was a fun one, thanks for sending it my way Brandon!

Cheeseman strikes again!  Pours a lightly hazy copper maroon, with a light white head.  Smells of yeast, sweet fruits, mild acidity and tannins, with a noticeable maltiness.  Very sharp biting sourness up front right away.  Nice acidic tannins and sweet sour fruits mixed together.  Not overly sweet which I enjoyed, but not totally dry either.  Nice little balance to it.  Not an upper echelon sour, but certainly better than average for me.

Tap @ their Portland Public House...  Poured into a snifter looking foggy, reddish with an off white head that created a ring around the glass throughout the whole brew.  Aroma of wine-like characters and almost lambic in nature.  Really thick palate that filled and expanded nicely in the mouth.  This brown style had a little more bitterness and darker malt notes than its Red counterpart, and it seemed the wild yeast really did a nice job with this recipe/batch.  You could taste a hint of barley-grains in the finish.  It was nice to have this in the same week as the Roots Flanders Red.  Even though they scored similar to me, it was nice to see the immediate contrast between the Brown style and the Red style.  Thanks to Mike Starzec for the complementary round.

Pours hazy amber with a ruby hue. A quarter inch head rose up before settling down to a placid surface, with a few errant dots of lacework.

Aromatics hit the nose as soon as the beer goes into the glass, with fruity acid wafting up.
Cherries, red wine, balsamic vinegar, ripe malt, and warming spice. Hints of cinnamon, peppercorns, cedar, sherry, and rhubarb follow through.

Medium bodied, with a lightly prickled mouthfeel, and drying.

Ripe, red fruits, acid, and oaky tannins are supported by a malty base on the palate.
As the brew warms hints of subtle spice step forward. Nutmeg, anise, and Schezuan peppercorns. Plenty of acid without being lactic or sour. 

Finishes with cherries, sherry, balsamic, pepper-studded earthy cedar, and warming alcohol. 

Wowza. Great beer now, but just wait a few years for this one to really meld, mellow, and complexify. The Pinot Noir barrels add a tremendous depth that is not typically found in Oud Bruins.
The tartness level now is firm, but allows the brew to be very drinkable. Im curious to see if some cellar time will add much sourness.

Do yourself a favor and let this one warm up to room temperature.

Big ups to BA Urwatuh8 for answering the call once more!

Bottle shared by durhambeer.  Pours a hazy dark amber with a small white head. Nose is cherry pits, tannins, oak, light tartness.  Flavor is wood, cherry, nice malts.  Vinous and dry mouthfeel with the alcohol very well hidden. I expected to not think this was sour enough, but the lack of extreme sourness works well in this beer and as Oud Bruin it makes sense. Very nice interpretation of the style.  A very pleasant surprise.

Bottle thanks much to Eugene.  Tastes and smells like young wood to me... not the dusty, oaky, barrel wood, but more like freshly cut wood.  More wood than sour cherry notes, but those are there as well in a tannic way.  Quite malty and the alcohol is well hidden.

Bottle, courtesy of golubj.  Poured a rich amber-auburn color with a medium, but quick diminishing head.  Aroma was nice, with sour, funky notes, cherries, fruit, earth, and oak.  Was not extremely sour, or maybe I am just getting more used to the style.  Alot of cherry in the flavor with hints of wood and cocoa.  Hints of barnyard funk and yeast, with generic fruit tones.  Actually really nice and I enjoyed it more than I thought I would.  Cant believe I rated it higher than Jon.

Great example of the style.  Thanks, WeeHeavySD, for this.  Its been on the radar for a while and I figured Id never try it. I have. Its delicious.  Tart, musky and exactly what I expected it to be.

22 oz. bottle courtesy of trades with both mashmaster and bitbucket.  As an aside before I begin my rating, I have to say that I really like the label graphics for this beer, very cool.  Thankfully, the wax on this bottle is soft and easy to cut through.  The beer itself pours a deep golden amber with a thin off-white head.  The aroma is pleasantly sour with just enough funk to give that barnyard smell but not be so strong as to mask the other attributes.  A generous amount of sour cherry in the nose as well.  The flavor is equally nice with old leather, barnyard funk, sour cherry and oak.  The tannins in the finish remind me more of a cabernet than of beer.  Sour ales are a style that I probably have the most difficulty with, as I really dont enjoy (and I guess appreciate) the uber sour beers, but this one I thought was just excellent.  My wife, who doesnt like sours at all, also thought this was very good.

Thanks to durhambeer for sharing. Pours a translucent copper red with a creamy light tan head. The nose is spicy, woody, cherry skin and flesh, mild alcohol, sweet, caramel malt, fruity, fig. Flavor is spicy and woody, crisp hoppy bitterness, tannic feel, mild tartness, cherry skins. Crisp bitterness with a balancing tannic character round out the mouthfeel. Dont feel 9%. Very tasty bruin.

Bottle, shared graciously by darkguardian on 12/30/08. Pours ruby with a wispy cream head. Nose is funky, wood, acidity, quite tart and sour with a little acetic character, soft vanilla from the barrel. Softer acidity in the mouth than the nose would suggest, tart, the wood really comes through. Tannic, puckering drying, medium to low carbonation makes it smoother. Not prickly. Very good at this point.

Thanks to Dark Guardian, I think.  Somewhat light smell of sour apples, tart cherries and a dusty apartment.  Tart cherries move into the flavor with some vinegar.  Not overly sour tasting and much lighter than the aroma would suggest.  Good, but I think would be better with even more sourness.

22 oz bottle.  Nice looking amber beer.  Nose is tart berries and wine.  Flavor is sour as all get out, but there is a nice sweetness that balances the infected flavors well.  Not a fan of sour beers, but this is pretty good.

22 oz bottle, shared by Axilla.  Pours a hazy amber body with a wispy beige head.  The nose is fairly funky with some cider vinegar and a bit of brett.  The flavor had a nice level of funk to it as well, not the most aggressive Sour, but it seemed pretty well balanced, some oak, tart fruit, it had a very vinous quality to it.  I could use a bit more brett flavor, maybe that will come with time?  Mouthfeel is light to medium bodied with light carbonation and a slightly puckering acidity.  Pretty decent, but not something that I loved.

Amazing sour courtesy Mr Stitch- Thanks man! Aroma was perfect- full and strong. Tart vinegar with sour fruit. Pour was also perfect. Medium brown with an amber hue and a nice pillowy 3 finger tan head. Taste was vinegar, sour raspberry and funk with woody undertones. Strong carbonation and very addictive. Near perfect in every way

text: UPDATED: JAN 4, 2009 thanks zeswaft.  bottle pour.  pours 1 inch tan foamy head and is burnt red and clear with lots of carbonation. smells pretty funky and farty,  flavor isnt super sour ale as much as it is like a jolly pumpkin.  but its actually a pretty good one. very mild infection flavors.  pretty sweet.  awesome.

22 oz. bottle shared by highibus - Pours a mahogany color with a thin off white head.  Light lacing.  The flavor and aroma is tart esters.  Soft carbonation and medium body.  A decent beer.  Thanks Tom.

Hand-waxed bottle shared with Theis, traded from toncatcher. Pours a beautiful clear red with strins of bubbles and an off-white head. Mildly sour with aromas of brett and berries. Medium body. Medium to soft carbonation. Slightly sticky mouthfeel. Bitter, bretty finish with faint aromas of coconutmilk. ’Bit too much brett. Thanks Dennis.

Tasted 11/15/08.  22oz bomber.  Filtered with a golden amber hue.  Spiraling off-white head.  Tart berry nose.  Woody and vinuous.  Cranberries and vanilla oak.  Big nose.  Medium to full bodied and bitter.  Red and black berries and totally tart.  Almost a wine and beer meld.  Good flavors and a great palate.  Big yet drinkable.  Robust yet balanced.  Tart fruity and vinegar, just what a sour should be!  Great job.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2009 Bottle at Sunes - thanks. Clear dark deep red/brown - white head. Dark malty, red berries, brett, coconut, light sourish, light wood, spicy, soil, light flowery. Nice - but a bit too much brett, needs more balsamic caracters.... Again: #22 - Amerikaner Blind-Smagning 01-Maj-2009 hos Papsoe. Bottle. (6/3/6/3/14)

Very pretty dark red with dirty white head. Pungant aroma of stinky cheese, dirty sweat socks, and ripe cherries. Oddly enough, all are good here. The flavor is pretty approachable. Robust vinager, lactic, a bit of fruit, and even a bit of malt character. Medium body and easy to drink. Very dry. I like this one quite a bit.

22oz. wax sealed bottle. Served in a Duvel tulip. Poured a reddish copper with a thin off white head. Nice lacing. Great sour fruit aroma. Not quite as sour as the aroma might suggest, but the brett flavor is spot on. Medium bodied with a spritzy mouthfeel. Sour cherry flavor develops, as well as a little wood in the finish. Very refreshing and drinkable. Alcohol is not evident. Very enjoyable.

Bottle...murky amber pour with a sizeable white head.  Nose has hints of granny smith apples, pears, lightly funky, a bit of sour cheese.  Medium body with great carbonation...flavor has a massive amount of sour apples which leads to a bread dough and sour cherry finish.  Very solid brew.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2010 9/15/2008

huge whiff of fresh cherries as the top is popped...

pours crystal clear a red cherry-ish amber color with a one inch pale tan head. 

initially lots of cherry in the aroma which fades to unveil metal, blood/iron/mineral, woody vanilla and cement-like bretty funk. it smells fairly sweet (for the style).

i get a lot of cinnamon flavor... along with ripe cherries, vanilla, caramel, toasted nuttiness and mineral-y bretty stink. there is a touch of malty sweetness to start. but, by the time the sip is over my tongue is dried off completely.... thanks brett! it*s tart and sour but not overly on either. the aftertaste lingers long into the night as fresh cherries. alcohol does come into play as it warms the sinus and chest the same way wine does... it*s quite pleasant. the medium body leans heavily on full. the carbonation gives it a creamy soft mouth feel which coats my mouth entirely yet it is spicy and prickly with a twangy kick.

2008 bomber via superdave on 7/4/10.

its not nearly as tart and fruity as it originally was but it is for sure much more funky. seems brett came in to dry the shit out of this! mmm

Bottle.  Pours clear tawny with an average, fizzy, off-white head, somewhat lasting with good lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (bread, hay, meal), average hops (flowers, grass), heavy yeast (horse blanket, barnyard) with notes of cherry and wood.  Medium bodied, sticky texture, average carbonation, and a sour finish.  Average duration, light sweetness, moderate acidity and sourness.

Bottle from the Co-op in Davis, CA. I;m always a little wary of sours. They tend to be a little too sour for me, but this one had a the perfect amount of sour. Nice balance of sour with sweet fruity flavors. Will try again.

I bought The Dissident without really knowing what it was.  I mean, I didnt even see who the brewer was.  But the label was so cutting, so dark, so angsty I couldnt say no.  The effect was only made more profound by its solitude on the shelf - no other Dissident in sight.  Very appropriate.  Also, Im not sure why, but from purchase to refrigeration, I thought the Dissident was going to be a deep, dark stout.  Imagine my surprise when I saw the less than dense pour and the smell of vinegar.  Instead, the beer is somewhat translucent, taken to the color of oak tree bark and a thin lily pad head of tan bubbles.  Alcohol commands the aroma, guiding vinous, wine-like qualities and a vinegar bite into my nose, resembling a Flemish Sour Ale in its woody, winey, sour scent portfolio.   The flavor is immediately familiar, but I cant label it at first.  Then I take a gander at the label.  Of course!  The Brett!  This beer is all about the Brett, bolstered by a dense traffic of carbonation, flavors of black cherries and oak, and a good, sharp ethanol bite.  The oak dryness and the alcohol cut almost to excess, but keep decorum where it counts, making this a very tasty, drinkable beer.  It may not have been an oil stout, but its got a lot of good flavor, and affirms that Brettanomyces has hurdled over the acquired taste status into a well loved and familiar flavor.
Pours a clear deep amber with some head.  Aroma of malt vinegar.  Sour black cherry flavor that is also somewhat sweet.  Nice hop finish.  Pretty good.

This was my first experience with a sour ale and I was very excited to try it out! Poured from a 22 oz bomber from the Bier Stein on thanksgiving and shared out with a few good friends. A very deep red pour, nearly brown even with a big white head. Has a vinegary essence but not in an unpleasant way, also smells of cherries and other fruit and some vanilla. The flavor at first was sweeter than I expected, but then that sour rush hits you like a knockout punch. Tasted kind of like a mild red wine but with cherry flavor instead of grapes. Interesting brew and I hope to try more sours in the future.

On tap at San Diego Brewing Co.  Murky red-brown color.  Couldnt quite see through glass.  Smell is sweet end of sour, and rich.  Taste is sweet and full.  Cherry, red wine.  Not as funky or sour as I expected.  Very accessible and enjoyable.  Flavors opened up as I worked down the 16 oz glass.  Yum

Stellar label.  Pours a shiny reddish brown color from the bomber.  Mild in aroma and flavor for a sour from my experience, but its more than welcomed.  Nice balance of caramel, yeast, unripe fruit, and oak.

Beautiful beer.  Bottle courtesy of nbutler11 in his newly minted pad.  A thick, ruby-brown pour.  Aroma of the expected Flemish variety but with a tart caramel balance to it.  Flavor of the same but the brown really comes through.  Wood, yeast, cereal as well.  What a fine, fine job.

Keg version, no way this is 11%, tastes like 7.  Surprisingly malty given the sourness.  Not much oak comes through until it warms a bit.  Good sourness and a good level. there of.  A candy sweet taste shows up but fades out when it warms.  A bit of oak character shows up and all the flavors meld together and everything really comes together as it warms a bit.

Aroma is sweet, red fruit, vinegar.  
Light amber, red fruit-beer puree color.
Taste is sweet, flabby, sour and sweet vinegar.  
Just not sour enough.  Dammit.  
Personal taste aside,  Lightly dms, slick mouthfeel, some sweet sourness...
Just very okay. Nothing challenging, easy-drinking. 
No way this is 9 percent.

Stunning brew with tons of complexity.  Odd also, with a malty but a sour that creaps in but not like any other sour I have had.  Should age nice for a couple years.  Better out of bottle than Keg.  Aroma and the unique sourness makes this beer outstanding.

Bottle from mashmaster, thanks! Reddish brown color. Vinous aroma with caramel, cherries, marzipan. Malty, fairly alcoholic, quite oaky flavor with hints of marzipan and cherries. Sour with  caramelly and coffee notes. Horseblanket. A good complexity, but just lacking a bit in balance. Nevertheless a great beer.

Strong aromas of oak, brett, and a little lighter aspect of tart cherries. Pours auburn with a thin head and sticky lace. The flavors has notes of tart cherries initially, a touch of sweetness. Oak follows and creates a dry sourness. Bretty funk comes in the finish and lingers with a touch of booze too. The tartness level is medium, the carbonation is rather bitey.

Darn. I paid a lot for this ($10) and was really hoping for something really special. From the 22 oz bottle this poured a cloudy dark orange with a small off-white head and very little lacing.  Nose was of sour cherry and vanilla.  Mouthfeel medium and somewhat fizzy from what I assume is the carbonation. Flavor is of sour fruit and the finish is a bit acrid.  Overall it was interesting, but I had a little trouble getting it all down. For me a bit of a disappointment. Maybe aged it would get better, but this is the only bottle I had and at this price probably the last.

Sample at the Columbus Ratebeer gathering at ogglethorps 11/20/08: This beer is a cloudy ruddy orange/amber color with a thin off-white head that dissipates slowly, leaving a ring around the outside. Stringy lacing. The aroma is sour cherries and apples, plus touches of vanilla. Medium-bodied with flavors of sour fruit, yeast and earthy malt. Interesting spice character in the background too. The finish is fruity with a vinous aftertaste. Pretty enjoyable overall.

Aroma is a sour fruit scent.  Color is a deep dark reddish brown with good carbonation and a thin tight head.  Taste is big, bold and sour.  Starting with a medium body it goes down with a crisp twang.  Finish comes in  with a bold sour taste that has cheery and oak tones, then there’s a dry vanilla taste.  In the after taste the sour feels almost sweet and yet dusty.  This is an interesting sour its complex but yet its delicate and bold all at once.

Bomber.  Pours a clear dark amber color with a soapy, medium sized off white head.  Has the appearance of a traditional Brown Ale.  Aroma is sweet maltiness, caramel, slight sour cherries.  This smells like a Barley Wine with just a touch of cherry tartness and a dash of acetic acid.  Some vanilla and wood notes are also noted.  Taste is malty, very slightly tart with some cherry fruitiness though it is subtle.  I expected this to be much more sour.  One positive note I can say is this hides its alcohol extremely well.  Other than that it pretty much tastes like a brown ale with some cherry syrup added.  I have another bottle of this that Ill give some more time to age and hopefully this will sour up.  As of now this is hugely disappointing.

22oz bomber poured into a snifter.

Pours a fairly clear copper red with a small creamy white head that lasts as a cap for the duration and leaves spotty lacing.

The aroma is full of sweet and tart fruits - certainly some cherry and raspberry notes. There is some funkiness, but nothing overpowering. Brown sugar and a bit of wood round out the nose.

The taste starts out with a tart fruit kick and gives way to the sweetness of the fruits and sugar. The finish is slightly dry with a definite wood presence.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied with strong carbonation that enhances the complex sweet/tart flavor mix.

This is a very drinkable Flanders and one that is not overpoweringly tart or funky. That makes it a very good beer in my book. I’ll definitely revisit this one over time and see how it ages.
Bottle. Poured dark reddish brown. Nose was funky with some tartness of cherry. Taste started sour and ended on a sweeter note. Overall a good beer and a great experimental beer.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2008 Bottle from Texas Liquor. Despite their high normally high prices, this bomber was worth the $12.99 I paid for it. Shared with Katie. Took me a while to dig through the liberal use of wax covering just to open the bottle. Pours a beautiful, dark ruby-brown color with a thick and frothy beige head. Perfect appearance here. Lovely nose of red wine, oak and yeast biscuit. Medium sourness flavor with caramel, earth and light chocolates. Finishes up tart with notes of cherries and brett yeast. Nicely carbonated on the palate with a lasting oak wood character. Well-played.

On tap @ Hamilton’s Tavern.  Pours a ruby red color with a nice sized beige head.  Nose of tart cherries and some farmhouse funk.  Flavor was slightly sour up front then got much sweeter towards the finish.  I waited a LONG time to try this beer, it didn’t disappoint.

Thanks to BOLTZ.   First of whats with having two layers of wax? Like one layer is not bad enough, but this pasteurized beer needs TWO LAYERS!  Once I was done removing the wax, the beer poured with a small head that quickly faded into a strong halo lacing.  Color is dark orange-ish copper, but completely clear.  Some carbonation bubbles visible through the beer.  Aroma is strong, it comes off as a super high octane Flanders Red made by an American brewer (as advertised, not exactly the best thing, imo).  It is not like a BFM strong Sour Red but its got some similar characteristics. There is cherry, lightly syrupy sourness, but it also has a lot of alcohol and some leafiness coming off the oak. Taste follows with a little bit more alcohol coming through especially at the end of the flavor.  It feels like I took a shot of liquor and I have a bit of an ethanol mistiness on the palate. Its a little prickly and pear-like as well, some light acidity in there.  Its strong, definitely strong and some of that gets in the way of the Flanders aspects.  Oak and alcohol on the back end, different, American, doable but I wont be able to do the same with many other beers like it.  Splitting the bottle with another person it was hard to keep drinking by the end with all the leafy oak and the alcohol.22oz bottle, Cantillon short stemmed copita glass.

text: really great looking, ruby red body with light white frothy head.  Big sour cherry bite uofront with a plethora of rustic, earthy notes highlighted by light oak and vanilla.  Great drink.

Poured a rusty brown with a foamy tan head. Nice carbonation. Delicious aroma of fruit, oakiness, malt, and sourness. Taste was of sour fruits including banana, cherries, and grapes. There was also toasty malt with oak flavors and yeast. No presence of alcohol in the taste. Lingering sour woodiness.

22oz bottle shared courtesy of Axilla (I think). Poured a deeper and cloudy orangish-brown color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of cherries, brett, earthy, wood, and caramel. Tastes of cherries, caramel, wood, fruity, brett, and a little vinous. Nice sour finsih. I’m glad I have some more of this and will spend some quality time with the next one!

Draft @ O’Bradys South Anchorage. Mahogany with a frothy tan head. Nicely oaked aroma with caramel tart cherry and lemon. Medium body and lightly carbonated. Mild to medium sour flavors are a good mesh of toasted caramel with cherry and lemon same as the aroma. No hint of the 11% in this draft version. Another hit from the Reserve Series.
